    Any class of public works or any part thereof may be done directly by the city without submitting the same for bids, upon three-fourths vote of all the members of the city council. When so ordered, the work shall be under the direction of the board of utility and public works. 
(Code 1993, § 1.20(4)) 
Secs. 2-280-2-306. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-307. - Members; terms. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall consist of eight members, two members of the council and six citizen members appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the members of the council. The council members' terms shall be for one year and they shall be appointed by the mayor at the annual organizational meeting of the council held on the third Tuesday of April. Citizen members shall be appointed for terms of three years at the annual organizational meeting of the council held on the third Tuesday of April. Their terms shall begin immediately upon appointment. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(1)) 
Sec. 2-308. - Vacancies; compensation. 
    If a vacancy occurs in any of the positions, the mayor may appoint a successor at any time to fill the unexpired term in that position, upon approval by the city council. Two members shall be appointed in each year for terms of three years. No compensation shall be paid for serving on the parks and recreations commission. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(1)) 
Sec. 2-309. - Meetings; quorum. 
    Meetings shall be held at least once each month. The commission shall elect a chairman and a secretary and notice of election shall be filed with the city clerk. Five members shall constitute a quorum and all actions shall require an affirmative approval of a majority of all the members. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(2)) 
Sec. 2-310. - Powers and duties. 
    The park and recreation commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Parks. With respect to parks, the powers and duties provided by Wis. Stats. §§ 27.08, 27.09 and 27.10. The acceptance of gifts of money or property or the acquisition of property or privileges for park purposes, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 27.08, can be accomplished only upon the recommendation of the commission and approval by the council by resolution, but the dedication of land or money in lieu thereof to the city for park, recreation or other public purposes in connection with the subdivision of land shall be deemed to have been approved by the council in and by its act of accepting the final plat in connection with which the dedication is made. The commission shall have charge of supervision over all city employees now employed or to be employed in the future for the purposes of repair, maintenance, upkeep and development of city park property. 
(2)  Recreation. The commission shall have the general supervision of municipal recreation in the city and shall operate and maintain all community recreation centers, playgrounds and other recreational areas and shall have the power to make rules and regulations for the government and control of all places of recreation, subject to the approval of a majority of all of the members of the council. The commission shall have the power to recommend a person to be appointed director of parks and recreation for the city. The commission shall promote recreation in its broadest aspects and toward this end shall cooperate with existing recreational programs under the auspices of the city school district. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(3a), (3b)) 
Sec. 2-311. - Budget. 
    The commission shall submit to the city council an estimate of the expenditures required for the subsequent calendar year in order to carry out a program for the maintenance, expansion, development and acquisitions of parks and recreational activities. The procedures used to perform this function shall be the same as those used by all other city departments. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(3c)) 
Sec. 2-312. - Finances. 
    The commission shall pay all incomes from recreational activities to the city treasurer. All expenditures pursuant to the budget previously approved by the city council shall be made only upon prior approval of the committee of the whole. The city clerk shall thereupon draw his order upon the treasurer and the same shall be paid as other municipal orders are paid. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(3d)) 
Sec. 2-313. - Park rules and regulations. 
    The parks and recreation commission is hereby authorized to adopt rules and regulations for the proper use, care and operation of the property under its control, provided the rules and regulations shall not conflict with the laws of this state or any rules or regulations enacted by the council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.21(3e)) 
Secs. 2-314-2-344. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY PLAN COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Plan commission, Wis. Stats. § 62.23. 

Sec. 2-345. - Membership; officers. 
    The city plan commission (that may also be referred to as the "plan commission" or the "planning commission") shall consist of seven members as follows: the mayor, who shall be its presiding officer, two alderpersons, and four citizens. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. The alderperson member shall be elected by a two-thirds vote of the council upon creation of the commission and during each April thereafter. The citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor. Citizen members shall take the official oath required by Wis. Stats. § 19.01 that shall be filed with the city clerk. As soon as practicable after May 1 of each year, the commission shall organize itself and elect a vice-chairman, secretary and other officers deemed necessary. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(1)-(3), (6)) 
Sec. 2-346. - Vacancies; compensation. 
    All vacancies on the plan commission shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as appointment for the full term. No compensation shall be paid for service on the plan commission. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(4)) 
Sec. 2-347. - Quorum; record of proceedings. 
    Four members shall constitute a quorum, but all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of all of the members of the city plan commission. The commission shall keep a written record of its proceedings to include all actions taken, a copy of which shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(7), (8)) 
Sec. 2-348. - Staff and budget. 
    The plan commission shall have the authority to employ experts and staff as may be necessary and proper within the limits of the budget established by the council or placed at its disposal through gift and subject to any ordinance or resolution enacted by the council. As far as possible, the commission shall utilize the services of existing city officials and employees. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(9), (10)) 
Sec. 2-349. - Powers and duties. 
    The plan commission shall have the powers and duties prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 62.23 and the other powers and duties as shall be vested in it from time to time by the council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(11)) 
Sec. 2-350. - Industrial development duties. 
    The plan commission shall have the power to collect, hold, manage, control and use all funds appropriated and provided for industrial development to collect, hold, manage, control and use all proceeds, earnings, and monies available for the sale, lease, rental, conveyance or other disposition of any property held or acquired; to construct, acquire by gift or purchase, reconstruct, improve or extend any industrial building within the city limits; and to acquire by gift or purchase lands or rights in lands in connection therewith in the name of the city; to develop an industrial park and to do or cause to be done all matters and things in connection therewith; to employ the personnel, agents, engineers, and consultants as the commission shall deem necessary; and to cause to be sold, leased, rented, conveyed, transferred, assigned, or donated any property acquired by the commission; and to exercise the other power and authority necessary to accomplish the purpose of this division. Provided, however, that any and all contracts entered into by the commission shall be subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(12)) 
Sec. 2-351. - Industrial development fund. 
    The industrial development fund previously created by ordinance is hereby re-established and shall be used for the purposes of financing and exercising the power of industrial development described above. Such fund shall consist of the sums of money as may be hereafter appropriated and provided for by the city council, and of all rentals, interest, income, dividends, earnings and monies available from the sale, lease, conveyance or other disposition of any property acquired pursuant to the power exercised by the commission under the terms of this division, and the other sums as may be provided for by ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(13)) 
Sec. 2-352. - Audit. 
    The commission shall cause all accounts, records and books concerning the management, operation and disbursements of the industrial development fund and of properties acquired thereby to be audited in the manner provided for by statute for the audit of public funds. 
(Code 1993, § 1.23(13)) 
Secs. 2-353-2-377. - Reserved.

Not more than three members of the commission shall belong to the same political party.

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Ambulance service, Wis. Stats. § 62.133. 

Sec. 2-406. - Composition; duties. 
    The ambulance commission shall consist of seven members, not less than four of whom shall be residents of the city. The commission shall supervise operation of the Tomah Area Ambulance Service; provided, however, that the supervision, management, equipment and control of the Tomah Area Ambulance Service, subject to the power herein vested in the ambulance commission, shall be in the council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(1), (3); Ord. No. 2009-07-06-D, § 1, 7-14-2009) 
Sec. 2-407. - Appointment; compensation. 
    Commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the council. The mayor shall designate the term of office of each commissioner so appointed. After original appointments, each member shall hold office three years, unless sooner removed for cause. No compensation shall be paid to any commission member. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(2)) 
Sec. 2-408. - Service area. 
    The Tomah Area Ambulance Service shall provide ambulance service for those cities, townships and villages within the service area which, for purposes of this division, is defined as consisting of those cities, townships and villages which have agreed to participate in the program. All cities, townships and villages within the definition of service area, in addition to the requirements herein, shall be required to execute a written agreement with the city. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(5), (8)) 
Sec. 2-409. - Service rates. 
    Charges for ambulance calls and services performed by the ambulance service shall be established by the commission and approved by the council. Charges shall be reviewed annually by the commission. All rate changes are subject to approval by the council after public hearing. Notice of public hearing shall be published as a class I publication as provided by statute. Current charges for services shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(4)) 
Sec. 2-410. - Rules and regulations. 
    The ambulance commission is hereby authorized to adopt rules governing its own proceedings and regulations for the proper use, care and operation of the property under its control, provided the rules and regulations do not conflict with the laws of the state or any ordinance or resolution enacted by the council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(6)) 
Sec. 2-411. - Cost sharing. 
    The expense of operating the Tomah Area Ambulance Service shall be shared by those municipalities that are within the Tomah area in accordance with the population of the municipalities, on the basis established by the city council. 
(Code 1993, § 1.26(9)) 
DIVISION 7. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-412. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is hereby declared a matter of public policy that the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of property, improvements, and materials of special architectural character or special historical interest or value is a public necessity and is required in the interest of health, prosperity, safety and welfare of the people. A historic preservation commission is hereby established, the purpose of which will be to: 
(1)  Effect and accomplish the protection, enhancement, and perpetuation of such historic structures, sites and districts which represent or reflect elements of the city's cultural, social economic, political, engineering and architectural history. 
(2)  Safeguard the city's historic and cultural heritage, as embodies and reflected in such historic structures, sites and districts. 
(3)  Stabilize and improve property values. 
(4)  Foster civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past. 
(5)  Protect and enhance the city's attractions to residents, tourists and visitors, and serve as a support and stimulus to business and industry. 
(6)  Strengthen the economy of the city. 
(7)  Promote the use of historic structures, sites and districts for the education, pleasure and welfare of the people of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04-06-D, § 1, 4-11-2017) 
Sec. 2-413. - Historic preservation commission composition. 
    A Historic preservation commission is hereby created, consisting of seven members. Of the membership, one shall be an alderperson, appointed annually by the mayor, one shall be a member of the city planning commission, one shall be a member of the long range planning committee, all remaining members shall be residents of the city of Tomah. Said persons shall be competent and informed in the historical, architectural and cultural traditions of the community. They shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council of the city of Tomah by majority vote. Of the initial members so appointed, two shall serve a term of one year, two shall serve a term of two years, and three shall serve a term of three years. Thereafter, the term for each member shall be three years. A vacancy occurring in the membership for any cause shall be filled by a person appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the common council for the unexpired term. The members of said commission shall receive no compensation except for necessary expenses sustained in carrying out their duties, which expenses shall be paid by the city of Tomah as may be authorized by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04-06-D, § 2, 4-11-2017) 
Sec. 2-414. - Historic preservation commission power and duties. 
(a)  Designation or rescission of historic structures, historic sites, and historic districts. The historic preservation commission may recommend designation or rescission of historic structures, historic sites, or historic districts within the city of Tomah. Designation or rescission of historic structures, historic sites and historic districts must be approved by the planning commission and the common council. In addition, any designation or rescission of a historic structure, historic sites or historic districts located within the boundary of the city's downtown master plan must also be reviewed by the city's long range planning committee prior to common council adoption. 
(b)  Review and approve applications for certificate of appropriateness. The commission shall review and approve applications for certificate of appropriateness under chapter 10, section 10-406 (alterations, or demolition of historic structures, historic sites, or historic districts) of the city of Tomah Municipal Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Other duties. In addition to those duties already specified in this section, the commission shall: 
(1)  Work for the continuing education of the citizens of Tomah about the historic heritage of this city and the historic structures, historic sites, and historic districts designated under the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Conduct local preservation planning efforts, often in conjunction with the planning department. The commission would conduct or supervise an on-going survey to identify and evaluate properties of historical, prehistorical or architectural interest, prepare reports of its findings and sponsor educational activities in the community. 
(3)  Cooperate with the historic preservation officer for the State of Wisconsin, and the state historic preservation review board, in attempting to include such properties hereunder designated as historic structures, historic sites, or historic districts in the National Register of Historic Places. 
(4)  As it deems advisable, the commission shall receive and solicit funds for the purpose of historic preservation in the city of Tomah. Such funds shall be placed in a special city account for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04-06-D, § 3, 4-11-2017) 
Secs. 2-415-2-435. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-436-2-453. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LAKE COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-454. - Creation; purpose. 
    The lake committee of the city is an advisory committee which assists the common council in the performance of its duties to the city. The committee shall serve as a venue to thoroughly investigate and debate issues involving Lake Tomah. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07-06-C, § 1(2.09(1)), 7-10-2007) 
Sec. 2-455. - Membership. 
    The lake committee shall consist of seven members. At least six of the committee members shall be electors (citizens) of the lake protection and rehabilitation district, however, not more than one non-elector member may be selected from the Drainage Area Boundary Map dated 1/5/2011. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07-06-C, § 1(2.09(2)), 7-10-2007; Ord. No. 2016-06-05-D, § 1, 6-14-2016) 
Sec. 2-456. - Term of members. 
    The term of citizen members shall be three years each, and the term of the aldermanic member shall be one year. Members shall be appointed by the mayor, upon approval by the city council, at the annual organizational meeting of the council. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07-06-C, § 1(2.09(3)), 7-10-2007) 
Sec. 2-457. - Meetings and quorum. 
    Meetings shall be held at the direction of the public works and utilities director, city administrator or common council. Four members shall constitute a quorum and all actions shall require an affirmative approval of a majority of all of the members. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07-06-C, § 1(2.09(4)), 7-10-2007) 
Sec. 2-458. - Powers and duties. 
    The lake committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To serve as a liaison between the community and the common council on issues involving Lake Tomah. 
(2)  To discuss and review any and all proposed ordinances or resolutions involving Lake Tomah and make recommendations to the common council regarding the necessity and appropriateness of the same. 
(3)  To review and make recommendations to the mayor and common council regarding the annual work plans and long-range goals for Lake Tomah. 
(4)  To review any other miscellaneous business involving Lake Tomah that may come from time to time and recommend a course of action to the common council. 
(Ord. No. 2007-07-06-C, § 1(2.09(5)), 7-10-2007) 
Secs. 2-459-2-484. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-485. - Composition; residency; compensation. 
    The community development block grant committee shall consist of five citizen members and an alderperson. The citizen members and the aldermanic member shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council. No compensation shall be paid for serving on the community development block grant committee. 
Sec. 2-486. - Term of office. 
    The term of citizen and aldermanic members shall be one year each. They shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council at the annual organizational meeting of the council held the third Tuesday in April. 
Sec. 2-487. - Meetings; rules and regulations. 
    The members of the community development block grant committee shall elect the officers, hold the meetings and establish the rules and regulations as it shall deem necessary and proper for carrying on its functions. Four members constitute a quorum. 
Sec. 2-488. - Powers and duties. 
    The committee shall review loan applications and make recommendations to the council as to whether or not low interest or deferred payment loans should be awarded to homeowners for home improvements or to business owners for the promotion of economic development in the city. 
Secs. 2-489-2-514. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - JOINT CITY/SCHOOL PLANNING COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-515. - Composition. 
    The joint city/school planning committee shall consist of two members of the common council, two members of the school board, city administrator, police chief, school superintendent and one school administrator. 
Sec. 2-516. - Appointment; terms. 
    The members, other than the four school representatives, shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council at the annual organizational meeting of the council held the third Tuesday in April. The term of office shall be one year. 
Sec. 2-517. - Purpose and duties. 
    The purpose of the committee is to review issues of mutual concern between the city and the city school district. Five members of the joint city/school planning committee shall constitute a quorum. 
Secs. 2-518-2-542. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-543. - Composition. 
    The emergency management committee shall consist of the mayor, city administrator, chief of police, fire chief, director of public works and utilities, ambulance director, safety director for the VA Medical Center, safety director for Tomah Memorial Hospital, county civil defense director and the city attorney. 
Sec. 2-544. - Appointment; term; quorum. 
    The members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council at the annual organizational meeting of the council held the third Tuesday in April. The terms of office shall be one year. Six members of the emergency management committee shall constitute a quorum. 
Sec. 2-545. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the committee is to work toward obtaining and maintaining emergency readiness in the city. 
Secs. 2-546-2-555. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LONG RANGE PLANNING COMMITTEE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-01-01-D, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 2009, enacted provisions intended for use as Div. 6, §§ 2-546-2-548. To preserve the style of this Code, and to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been redesignated as Div. 6, §§ 2-556-2-558. 

Sec. 2-556. - Creation; purpose. 
    The long range planning committee is an advisory committee which assists the common council in the performance of its duties to the city. The committee shall serve as a venue to thoroughly re-evaluate the existing corporate limits of the city with a view of the revitalization of presently occupied areas as well as undeveloped sections of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-01-01-D, § 1, 1-13-2009) 
Sec. 2-557. - Composition; term; quorum; meetings. 
    The long range planning committee shall consist of the mayor, two members of the common council, and seven members with two of said members being members of the planning commission. The council member terms shall be for two years. Members shall be appointed by the mayor at the annual organizational meeting of the council subject to confirmation by the council. After original appointments, each of the remaining members shall hold office three years, unless sooner removed for cause. Six members shall constitute a quorum, but all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of all members of the committee. The members shall elect the officers and hold the meetings as necessary and proper for carrying on its functions. 
(Ord. No. 2009-01-01-D, § 1, 1-13-2009) 
Sec. 2-558. - Powers and duties. 
The long range planning committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To serve as a liaison between the community and the common council on long-range issues involving the city. 
(2)  To discuss, review and make recommendations to the mayor, planning commission and/or common council regarding the city's comprehensive land use plan. 
(3)  To discuss, review and make recommendations to the mayor, planning commission and/or common council regarding any and all long-range planning issues or goals for the city including but not limited to land use, annexation, zoning, economic development, capital improvements, infrastructure, grant opportunities or any other issue as directed by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 2009-01-01-D, § 1, 1-13-2009) 
Secs. 2-559-2-568. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AUTHORITIES AND BUREAUS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-569-2-599. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOUSING AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-600. - Composition; residency; compensation. 
    The city's housing authority shall consist of five citizens and one nonvoting alderperson. Per a resolution dated November 26, 1976, the common council desires that the project coordinator of the community development block grant program act as its representative on the said housing authority committee. The aldermanic and citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council. No compensation shall be paid for serving on the housing authority. 
Sec. 2-601. - Terms of office. 
    The term of citizen members shall be five years each. The council member's term shall be for one year. The members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council at the annual organizational meeting of the council held on the third Tuesday in April. 
Sec. 2-602. - Meetings; rules and regulations. 
    The members of the housing authority shall elect the officers, hold the meetings and establish the rules and regulations as it shall deem necessary and proper for carrying on its functions. Three members constitute a quorum. 
Sec. 2-603. - Powers and duties. 
    To provide oversight and direction in the administration of the authority towards the goal of providing safe, sanitary affordable housing to low and moderate income households. 
Secs. 2-604-2-624. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU 

Sec. 2-625. - Composition; residency; compensation. 
    The city's convention and visitors bureau (CVB) shall consist of eight directors. Appointed directors shall include: one representing the common council; one representing the Greater Tomah Area Chamber of Commerce board of directors; one representing the Monroe County Agricultural Society; one being the city administrator; two representing a city motel/hotel; one representing a city retail establishment; and one representing a city restaurant or bar. The mayor shall appoint members subject to confirmation by the common council. No compensation shall be paid for serving on the Tomah Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
(Ord. No. 2012-09-06-D, § 1, 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 2-626. - Terms of office. 
(a)  Administrative members. The term of office for the following shall be one year: Representative of the common council, city administrator and a representative of the Greater Tomah Area Chamber of Commerce board of directors. Any administrative member shall not be subject to a term limit and would be eligible for reappointment by the mayor on an annual basis. 
(b)  Citizen members. The term of office for the following members shall be three years: representative of the Monroe County Agricultural Society, representative of city retail establishment, two representatives of a city motel/hotel and a representative of a city restaurant or bar. Any and all citizen members shall be subject to a term limit of three consecutive years. Provided, however, citizen members shall be eligible for reappointment after being off the board for at least one full year. 
(c)  Appointment. The members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council at the annual organizational meeting of the council held the third Tuesday in April. In case of any interim vacancy on the board through death, resignation, removal or other cause, a successor shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2012-09-06-D, § 2, 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 2-627. - Meetings, rules and regulations. 
    Regular meetings shall be held every other month at a time approved by the convention and visitors bureau (CVB) board of directors. Five members of the CVB board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at all meetings of the CVB board. At the regular meeting following the organizational meeting of the council, the CVB board of directors shall elect a chairperson and vice-chair for a one-year term. 
(Ord. No. 2012-09-06-D, § 3, 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 2-628. - Powers and duties. 
    The affairs of the convention and visitors bureau, along with the control and management of its business and property shall be directed by the executive director upon approval of the CVB board of directors. Duties include: 
(1)  The elected CVB chairperson shall be the legislative head of the CVB and shall preside at all meetings of the CVB board of directors. Subject to the approval of the CVB board of directors, the chairperson shall be responsible for the signing of all notices, minutes, reports and contracts affecting the operation of the CVB and its property. 
(2)  The vice-chairperson shall perform the duties of the chairperson in his absence. Subject to approval of the CVB board of directors, the vice-chairperson may succeed the chairperson. 
(3)  The executive director of the CVB shall perform such responsibilities as assigned by the CVB board. Subject to the approval of the CVB board of directors, the executive director shall prepare an operating budget, and be responsible for all operating expenditures in accordance with the approved budget. The executive director shall prepare all meeting notices, and be responsible for proper media notice in accordance with the Wisconsin Open Meetings Law. The executive director shall also make monthly and year end financial reports to the board of directors. 
(4)  The executive director and/or staff of the CVB shall be responsible for all minutes of the CVB meetings. 
(5)  Responsible for establishing procedure and formulating policy for the organization that is consistent with and subordinate to the bylaws of the Greater Tomah Area Chamber of Commerce. Procedure and policies shall be maintained, reviewed and revised by the CVB board of directors as deemed necessary. 
Secs. 2-629-2-659. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC RECORDS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Public records, Wis. Stats. § 19.21 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-660. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authority means any city entity having custody of a city record including an office, elected official, agency, board, commission, committee, council, department or public body corporate and politic created by constitution, law, ordinance, rule or order or a formally constituted subunit of the foregoing. 
    Custodian means that officer, department head, division head or employee of the city designated herein or otherwise responsible by law to keep and preserve any city records or files, deposit or keep the records in his office or is lawfully in possession or entitled to possession of the public records and who is required by this division to respond to requests for access to the records. 
    Record means any material on which written, drawn, printed, spoken, visual or electromagnetic information is recorded or preserved regardless of physical form or characteristics, that has been created or is being kept by an authority. The term "record" includes, but is not limited to, handwritten, typed or printed pages, maps, charts, photographs, films, recordings, tapes (including computer tapes) and computer printouts. The term "record" does not include drafts, notes, preliminary computations and like materials prepared for the originator's personal use or prepared by the originator in the name of a person for whom the originator is working; materials which are purely the personal property of the custodian and have no relation to his office; materials to which access is limited by copyright, patent or bequest; and published library materials which are available for sale or which are available for inspection at a public library. 
(Code 1993, § 1.40) 
Sec. 2-661. - Duty to maintain. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, each officer and employee of the city shall safely keep and preserve all records received from his predecessor or other persons and required by law to be filed, deposited or kept in his office or employee or his deputies or to the possession or control of which they may be lawfully entitled as the officers or employees. 
(Code 1993, § 1.41(1)) 
Sec. 2-662. - Surrender of records. 
    Upon the expiration of an officer's term of office or an employee's term of employment or whenever the office or position of employment becomes vacant, each the officer or employee shall deliver to his successor all records then in his custody and the successor shall receipt therefor to the officer or employee, who shall file the receipt with the city clerk. If a vacancy occurs before a successor is selected or qualifies, the records shall be delivered to and receipted for by the clerk on behalf of the successor to be delivered to the successor upon the latter's receipt. 
(Code 1993, § 1.41(2)) 
Sec. 2-663. - Legal custodian. 
(a)  Designation. Each elected official is the legal custodian of the records of his office, but the official may designate an employee of his staff to act as the legal custodian. Unless otherwise prohibited by law, the city clerk or the clerk's designee shall act as legal custodian for the council and for any committees, commissions, boards or other authorities created by ordinance or resolution of the council; provided, however that the council may by resolution designate the legal custodian for these committees, commissions, boards or other authorities as it deems appropriate. Each legal custodian shall name a person to act as legal custodian in his absence or the absence of his designee. 
(b)  Authority. The legal custodian shall have full legal power to render decisions and to carry out the duties of an authority under Wis. Stats. §§ 19.21-19.39 and this section. The designation of a legal custodian does not affect the powers and duties of an authority under this section. 
(Code 1993, § 1.42) 
Secs. 2-664-2-684. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INSPECTION AND DUPLICATION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Public records and property, Wis. Stats. § 19.21 et seq. 

Sec. 2-685. - Access to records. 
(a)  Access; adoption of state law. The rights of any person who requests inspection or copies of a record are governed by the provisions and guidelines of Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1) which is hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)  Provision of equipment and facilities. Each authority shall provide any person who is authorized to inspect or copy a record that appears in written form, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1)(b), or any person who is authorized to and requests permission to photograph a record, the form of which does not permit copying pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1)(f), with facilities comparable to those used by its employees to inspect, copy and abstract the record during established office hours. An authority is not required by this subsection to purchase or lease photocopying, duplicating, photographic or other equipment or to provide a separate room for the inspection, copying or abstracting of records. 
(c)  Response to requests for access. Each authority in acting upon a request for any record shall respond within the times and according to the procedures set out in Wis. Stats. § 19.35(4). 
(d)  Notice to public. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 19.34, each authority shall adopt, prominently display and make available for inspection and copying at its offices for the guidance of the public, a notice containing a description of its organization and the established times and places at which, the legal custodian from whom, and the methods whereby the public may obtain information and access to records in its custody, make requests for records or obtain copies of records and the costs thereof. Each authority shall also prominently display at its offices for the guidance of the public a copy of Wis. Stats. §§ 19.31 to 19.39. This subsection does not apply to members of the city council. 
(e)  Limitations on right to access; adoption of state law. Wis. Stats. § 19.36 is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1993, §§ 1.43, 1.44) 
Sec. 2-686. - Separation of information. 
    If a record contains information that may be made public and information that may not be made public, the authority having custody of the record shall provide the information that may be made public and withhold the information that may not be made public from the record before release. Each authority shall consult with the city attorney before releasing any information under this section. 
(Code 1993, § 1.45) 
Sec. 2-687. - Fees. 
(a)  Reproduction and transcription. Each authority shall impose a fee upon the requestor of a copy of a record that may not exceed the actual, necessary and direct cost of reproduction and transcription of the record, unless a fee is otherwise specifically established or authorized to be established by the law. 
(b)  Photographic reproduction. Each authority shall impose a fee upon the requester of a copy of a record for the actual, necessary and direct cost of photographing and photographic processing if the authority provides a photograph of a record, the form of which does not permit copying. 
(c)  Records research. Except as otherwise provided by law or as authorized to be prescribed by law, an authority shall impose a fee upon a requester for locating a record, not exceeding the actual, necessary and direct cost of location, if the cost is $50.00 or more. 
(d)  Mailing and shipping costs. Each authority shall impose a fee upon a requester for the actual, necessary and direct cost of mailing or shipping of any copy or photograph of a record that is mailed or shipped to the requester. 
(e)  Partial or complete waiver of fees. An authority may provide copies of a record without charge or at a reduced charge where the authority determines that waiver or reduction of the fee is in the public interest. 
(f)  Prepayment of fees. Each authority shall require prepayment by requester of any fee imposed under this section if the total amount exceeds $5.00. 
(Code 1993, § 1.48) 
Sec. 2-688. - Certain records of the assessor. 
    Whenever the assessor in the performance of his duties requests or obtains income and expense information, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af) or any successor statute, the income and expense information that is provided to the assessor shall be held by him on a confidential basis. Such information, unless otherwise ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction, is not subject to the right of inspection and copying under Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1); provided, however, that this section shall not apply to information revealed to and used by persons: 
(1)  Pursuant to order of court; 
(2)  In the discharge of duties imposed by law; and 
(3)  In the discharge of duties imposed by office including, but not limited to, use by the assessor in performance of official duties of the assessor's office and use by the board of review in performance of its official duties. 
(Code 1993, § 1.49) 
Secs. 2-689-2-719. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RECORDS RETENTION 

Sec. 2-720. - Destruction of records generally. 
    Destruction of records shall be in accordance with the provisions of this article and state law. Unless notice is waived by the state historical society, at least 60 days' notice shall be given the state historical society prior to the destruction of any record as provided by Wis. Stats. § 19.21(4)(a). 
(Code 1993, § 1.46(4)) 
Sec. 2-721. - Tape and other recordings. 
    Any tape or other audio or audio/visual recordings of a governmental meeting of the city may be destroyed, erased or reused no sooner than 90 days after the minutes of the meeting have been approved and published, if the purpose of the recording was to make minutes of the meeting. 
(Code 1993, § 1.46(5)) 
Sec. 2-722. - Non-utility records. 
    City officers may destroy the following non-utility financial records of which they are the legal custodians and which are considered obsolete after completion of any required audit by the bureau of municipal audit or an auditor licensed under Wis. Stats. ch. 422, but not less than seven years after payment or receipt of any sum involved in the particular transaction, unless a shorter period has been fixed by the state public records board, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 16.61(3)(e), and then, after the shorter period: 
(1)  Water stubs and receipts of current billings. 
(2)  Customer ledgers. 
(3)  Vouchers and supporting documents pertaining to charges not included in plant accounts. 
(4)  Bank statements. 
(5)  Canceled checks. 
(6)  Receipt forms. 
(7)  Vouchers. 
(8)  Bonds and coupons after maturity. 
(9)  License and permit applications. 
(10)  Justice dockets. 
(11)  Resolutions and petitions. 
(12)  Correspondence. 
(13)  Oaths of office. 
(Code 1993, § 1.46(1)) 
Sec. 2-723. - Obsolete records. 
    City officers may destroy the following records of which they are legal custodian and which are considered obsolete, but not less than seven years after the record was effective, unless a shorter period has been fixed by the state public records board, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 16.61(3)(e), and then after the shorter period: 
(1)  Old insurance policies. 
(2)  Election notices. 
(3)  Canceled registration cards. 
(4)  Contracts and papers relating thereto. 
(5)  Financial reports other than annual financial reports. 
(Code 1993, § 1.46(3)) 
Sec. 2-724. - Utility records. 
    City officers may destroy the following utility records of which they are the legal custodians and which are considered obsolete after completion of any required audit by the bureau of municipal audit or an auditor licensed under Wis. Stats. ch. 422, subject to state public service commission regulations, but not less than seven years after the record was effective, unless a shorter period has been fixed by the state public records board, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 16.61(3)(e), and then after the shorter period, except that water stubs, receipts of current billings and customers' ledgers may be destroyed after two years: 
(1)  Contracts. 
(2)  Excavation permits. 
(3)  Inspection records. 
(4)  Special assessment records. 
(5)  Licenses and permits. 
(Code 1993, § 1.46(2)) 
Secs. 2-725-2-746. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FINANCE[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal finance, Wis. Stats. § 62.12; municipal finance, revenue, Wis. Stats. § 66.0601 et seq.; local government purchasing, Wis. Stats. § 66.0131; interest on late payments, Wis. Stats. § 66.0135. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-747. - Fiscal year. 
    The calendar year shall be the fiscal year of the city. 
(Code 1993, § 3.03) 
Sec. 2-748. - Transfer of appropriations. 
    Upon recommendation of the committee of the whole, the council may, at any time by a two-thirds vote of the entire membership, transfer any portion of an unencumbered balance of an appropriation to any other purpose or object. Notice of the transfer shall be given by publication within ten days thereafter in the official city newspaper as required by Wis. Stats. § 65.90(5)(a). 
(Code 1993, § 3.05) 
Sec. 2-749. - Expenditure of city funds. 
    No money shall be drawn from the treasury of the city, nor shall any obligation for the expenditure of money be incurred, except in pursuance of the annual appropriation in the adopted budget or when changed as authorized in this article. At the close of each fiscal year, any unencumbered balance of an appropriation shall revert to the general fund and shall be subject to reappropriation, but appropriations may be made by the council to be paid out of the income of the current year in furtherance of improvements or other objects or works which will not be completed within the year, and any appropriation shall continue in force until the purpose for which it was made shall have been accomplished or abandoned. 
(Code 1993, § 3.06(1)) 
Sec. 2-750. - Signing of orders. 
    All order checks drawn on the city treasury shall be signed by the city treasurer, city clerk and mayor or their respective designees. 
(Code 1993, § 3.06(2)) 
Secs. 2-751-2-768. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PAYMENT OF CLAIMS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Claims and actions, Wis. Stats. § 62.25. 

Sec. 2-769. - General procedure. 
(a)  Certification. Prior to submission of any account, demand or claim to the city council for approval of payment, the committee of the whole shall certify by indicating its approval on each claim that funds are available therefor pursuant to the budget, the item or service was authorized by the proper official or agency and has been received or rendered in accordance with the purchasing agreement, and the claim is accurate in amount and a proper charge against the treasury. 
(b)  Report to city council. At the next regular meeting of the city council, the committee of the whole shall present to the city council its report as to claims allowed. The city council may approve or reject the report in whole or in part and may approve the payment of additional accounts, demands and claims. However, no account, demand or claim shall be allowed by the city council until it has been reviewed by the committee of the whole. No regular monthly account, demand or claim against the city, except as otherwise provided herein, shall be paid unless it has been allowed by the city council by approval of the committee of the whole's report or other action of the council. The city clerk shall mark each account, demand or claim not approved with the appropriate legend. 
(Code 1993, § 3.02(1), (2)) 
Sec. 2-770. - Alternative procedure. 
    Should it be deemed necessary that payments be made from the city treasury other than designated in section 2-769, the council may authorize that those payments may be made weekly only after the city administrator audits and approves each claim as a proper charge against the treasury and endorses his approval on the claim after having determined: 
(1)  That funds are available pursuant to the budget approved by the governing body. 
(2)  That the item or service covered by the claim has been duly authorized by the proper official, department head, board or commission. 
(3)  That the item or service has been actually supplied or rendered in conformity with the authorization. 
(4)  That the claim is just and valid pursuant to law. The city administrator may require the submission of the proof and evidence to support the foregoing as in that officer's discretion may be deemed necessary. 
(Code 1993, § 3.02(4a)) 
Sec. 2-771. - Wages and salaries. 
    Regular wages or salaries of city officers and employees shall be paid by payroll, verified by the proper city official, department head, board or commission and filed with the city accounting department in time for payment on the regular payday. 
(Code 1993, § 3.02(3)) 
Sec. 2-772. - Monthly list of claims. 
    A monthly list of all claims that are paid pursuant to this article shall be provided to the committee of the whole for approval. Said list shall show the date paid, name of claimant, purpose and amount. The monthly resolution submitted to the city council for approval that authorizes payment of bills shall include the total of payments made during that month that were authorized by the city administrator under this section. 
(Code 1993, § 3.02(4b)) 
Sec. 2-773. - Annual audit. 
    The common council of the city shall authorize an annual detailed audit of its financial transactions and accounts by a public accountant licensed under state law and designated by the governing body. 
(Code 1993, § 3.02(4c)) 
Secs. 2-774-2-799. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUDGET PROCEDURE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Budgets, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.12(2), 65.90. 

Sec. 2-800. - Departmental estimates. 
    On or before October 1 of each year, each officer, department or board shall file with the city administrator an itemized statement of disbursements made to carry out the powers and duties of the officer or department during the preceding fiscal year, a detailed statement of the receipts and disbursements on account of any special fund under the supervision of the officer or department during the year and of the condition and management of the fund, and also detailed estimates of the same matters for the current fiscal year and for the ensuing fiscal year. Such statement shall be presented in the form prescribed by the city administrator, shall be designated by the term "departmental estimates," and shall be as nearly uniform as possible for the main divisions of all departments. 
(Code 1993, § 3.04(1)) 
Sec. 2-801. - Consideration and recommendation. 
    The committee of the whole shall consider the departmental estimates in consultation with the city administrator and shall then determine the total amount to be recommended in the budget for the department or activity. 
(Code 1993, § 3.04(2)) 
Sec. 2-802. - Proposed budget. 
    If possible, on or before October 28 each year, the committee of the whole shall prepare and submit to the city council a proposed budget presenting a financial plan for conducting the affairs of the city for the ensuing calendar year. In lieu of a committee of the whole proposed budget, an executive budget prepared by the city administrator shall be presented to the council. The council shall provide a reasonable number of copies of the prepared budget for distribution to citizens. 
(Code 1993, § 3.04(3a), (3b)) 
Sec. 2-803. - Contents of proposed budget. 
    The budget shall include the following information: 
(1)  Anticipated expenses. The expense of conducting each department and activity of the city for the ensuing fiscal year and corresponding items for the current year and last preceding fiscal year, with reasons for increases and decreases recommended as compared with appropriations for the current year. 
(2)  Anticipated income. An itemization of all anticipated income of the city from sources other than general property taxes and bond issues, with a comparative statement of the amounts received by the city from each of the same or similar sources for the last preceding and fiscal years. 
(3)  General property tax revenues. An estimate of the amount of money to be raised from general property taxes that, with income from other sources, will be necessary to meet the proposed expenditures. 
(4)  Other information. Such other information as may be required by the council and by state law. 
(Code 1993, § 3.04(3c)) 
Sec. 2-804. - Hearing. 
    The committee of the whole shall submit to the council at the time the annual budget is submitted the draft of an appropriate resolution providing for the expenditures proposed for the ensuing fiscal year. Upon the submission of the proposed appropriation resolution to the council, it shall be deemed to have been regularly introduced therein. The council shall hold a public hearing on the budget and the proposed appropriation resolution as required by law. Following the public hearing, the proposed appropriation resolution may be changed or amended and shall take the same course in the council as other resolutions. 
(Code 1993, § 3.04(4)) 
Secs. 2-805-2-831. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ETHICS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Ethics for public officials generally, Wis. Stats. § 19.41 et seq.; code of ethics for local government officials and employees, Wis. Stats. § 19.59. 

Sec. 2-832. - Declaration of policy. 
    Where government is based on consent of the governed, every citizen is entitled to have complete confidence in the integrity of government. Public officials and employees must help earn, preserve and honor that trust by their integrity and conduct. In recognition of these goals there is hereby established a code of ethics for all city officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid, including members of all city boards, commissions and committees. 
(Code 1993, § 1.08(1)) 
Sec. 2-833. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Appointed official means any officer of the city appointed pursuant to the authority set forth in Wis. Stats. § 62.09 who is compensated for official services to the city; any appointed member of a city board, commission or committee serving with compensation; city agency heads and their designated deputies. 
    Business means a corporation, partnership, proprietorship, franchise, association, organization, self-employed individual or any legal entity engaged in profit-making activities. 
    Candidate for elective office means any individual who is required to file nomination papers and register with the city clerk as a candidate for elective office pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 8.10. 
    Declaration of economic interest means the statement prescribed by and filed with the city ethics board pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
    Economic interest means any of the economic interests defined in Wis. Stats. § 19.44. 
    Elected official means any official of the city serving in an elective office established pursuant to or under the authority of Wis. Stats. § 62.09. 
    Employee means any individual, other than an agency head and his designated deputy, who is employed by the city and receives a salary or wages for work performed on either a parttime or fulltime basis. The term shall apply to all individuals classified as temporary, probationary or permanent employees of the city. 
    Immediate family means the parent, stepparent, brother, sister, stepbrother, stepsister, grandparent, parent-in-law, spouse, child, stepchild, son-in-law or daughter-in-law of an appointed or elected official. 
    Official, as used in this article, includes both elected and appointed officials, as defined herein. 
(Code 1993, § 1.08(2)) 
Sec. 2-834. - Official misconduct. 
(a)  State law prohibitions. Wis. Stats. §§ 946.10 to 946.17 prohibit certain forms of conduct on the part of all public officials and employees and provide for the imposition of criminal penalties upon conviction for engaging in prohibited forms of conduct. Each city official and employee will be provided with a copy of these statutes by the city clerk upon taking office or entering employment. 
(b)  Gifts and favors. No official or employee shall accept any gift or favor, whether an article of value, loan, service or promise, from any individual, business or group which has either a direct or indirect interest in a matter pending before the city council, a board, commission, committee, city agency or office. Nor shall any official or employee accept any gift or favor that may tend to influence the discharge of their responsibilities or duties. 
(c)  Representing private interests. No official or employee, whose salary is paid in whole or in part by the city, shall appear in behalf of private interests before any board, commission, committee or agency of the city or in any litigation to which the city is a party except when subpoenaed as a witness by a party involved in the litigation. A member of the council may appear before a board, commission, committee or agency in behalf of constituents, providing no compensation is paid or gratuity provided to that member contingent upon a specific outcome in a matter of interest to a constituent. 
(d)  Substantial or controlling contractual interest. Any official or employee having a substantial or controlling financial interest in any business entity seeking or securing a contract with the city, or in the sale of real estate, vehicles, equipment, supplies, materials or services to the city, shall make the interest known in writing to the ethics board. The ethics board shall provide this information to the council and the city agencies affected. A member of the council with an interest shall ask to be excused from voting on or otherwise participating in the matter while it is before the council or one of its committees. 
(e)  Private interest in legislative matter. A member of the council who has a financial or other private interest in any legislative matter introduced for consideration before the council shall disclose the interest to the presiding officer and members of the council at the time the matter is introduced and shall ask to be excused from voting on or otherwise participating in the matter while it is before the council or one of its committees. A member of a city board, commission or committee who has a financial or other private interest in any matter on which the body is expected to act shall disclose the interest to the body at the time the matter is introduced and shall ask to be excused from voting on or otherwise participating in the matter while it is before the body. 
(f)  Use of public property. No official or employee shall request or permit the use of city-owned buildings, facilities, vehicles, equipment, materials or other city property for personal convenience or profit, except when the services are available to the public generally and except where otherwise authorized by action of the council. 
(g)  Use of information. No official or employee shall make use of or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, information not made available to the public. 
(h)  Political activity. No employee shall, during the hours in which they are performing responsibilities and duties as a city employee, engage in any activity calculated to benefit a political party, partisan or nonpartisan organization, campaign committee or candidate seeking to influence the outcome of an election or referendum. This prohibition extends to the direct or indirect solicitation of campaign contributions, including in-kind contributions, and the use of city owned buildings, facilities, vehicles, equipment, materials or other city property to influence the outcome of an election or referendum. 
(i)  Outside employment. No employee shall engage in any outside employment that might result in a conflict or the appearance of a conflict between the private interests of the employee and the employee's duties and responsibilities as a city employee. 
(Code 1993, § 1.08(3), (4)) 
Sec. 2-835. - Employee protection; untrue statements and prohibited disclosure. 
(a)  No appointing authority, agent of an appointing authority or supervisor may initiate or administer or threaten to initiate or administer any retaliatory action against a city employee following an employee's disclosure of information related to the violation of any federal or state law, city ordinance, rule or regulation, the mismanagement or abuse of authority, a substantial waste of public funds or a danger to public health and safety. 
(b)  Nothing in this section restricts the right of the city as an employer to take appropriate disciplinary action against an employee who knowingly makes an untrue statement or discloses information, the disclosure of which is specifically prohibited by federal or state law, rule or regulation. 
(Code 1993, § 1.08(8)) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOL BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcohol beverages, Wis. Stats. ch. 125; local option, Wis. Stats. § 125.05. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cabaret means a place to which the general public is admitted and where entertainment, such as singing, vaudeville or dancing, is furnished to patrons by the management, with or without special charge, and where alcohol beverages are sold. 
    Conditional renewal means a renewal of a license subject to specified conditions as determined by the committee of the whole and approved by the common council. Such conditions shall be made with the intention of promoting and ensuring the compliance of the license holder to the provisions of this chapter and Wis. Stats. ch. 125. 
    Offenses which substantially relate to the circumstances of the licensed activity shall include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Any nonfelony alcohol-related conviction or pending charges within the last 12 months. 
(2)  A history of nonfelony alcohol-related convictions as long as the most current conviction or arrest is within the last 24 months. 
(3)  Any nonfelony drug related convictions or pending charges within the last 12 months. 
(4)  Any nonfelony conviction or pending charges within the last 12 months which involve resisting arrest, battery to a police officer or obstructing justice in direct connection to activity at a licensed alcohol establishment. 
(5)  Two or more nonfelony convictions or pending charges in the last 24 months for disorderly behavior type offenses if they occurred in direct connection to activity at a licensed alcohol establishment. 
(6)  One or more felony convictions in the last five years involving alcohol, drugs or other behavior if it occurred in direct connection to activity at a licensed alcohol establishment. 
(7)  Any other arrest or conviction that is reasonably determined to be substantially related to the circumstances of the licensed activity. The reasons for such a determination shall be stated in writing with particularity by the governing body making said determination. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5), (7)-(9); Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-2. - Adoption of state law. 
    The provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 125 relating to intoxicating liquors and fermented malt beverages, inclusive of any provisions thereof relating to the penalty to be imposed or the punishment for violation of such statutes, are hereby adopted and made a part of this section by reference. A violation of any such provisions shall be a violation of this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the state statutes are incorporated herein and are intended to be made part of this chapter in order to secure uniform statewide regulation in the area of intoxicating liquors and fermented malt beverages. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(1)) 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation, Wis. Stats. § 125.10. 
Sec. 4-3. - Summary abatement procedure; disorderly houses; imminent health hazard. 
(a)  Duty to maintain order. A licensee under this section shall have the duty to maintain order and peace in and around the licensed premises and to maintain such premises in compliance with all applicable municipal and state codes dealing with building and health requirements. This duty shall include any premises specifically identified on the license or used in conjunction with the licensed premises. 
(b)  Police power to close licensed premises. The police department may order any disorderly house closed until 8:00 a.m. the following day when in the reasonable view of the department the licensee or person in charge has failed to maintain peace and order as per subsection (a) of this section or the department otherwise believes the public safety is served by such closing by reason of threat to the bodily security, property or peaceful repose of any member of the public. 
(c)  Building and health department authority to summarily abate public health and safety nuisances. In their capacity as agents to the department of health and social services or the department of industry, labor and human relations, the health inspector or building inspector may order the temporary suspension of a restaurant or beverage license issued under this chapter where imminent health or safety hazards exist on a licensed premises pending a hearing pursuant to state administrative code procedures. Such closing may act as grounds for suspension or revocation of liquor licenses issued under this chapter. 
Secs. 4-4-4-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-23. - Controlling provisions. 
    Applicants for and holders of alcohol beverage licenses within the city shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter and chapter 12, pertaining to businesses and business regulations, in addition to all other applicable city, state, and federal laws. In the event of conflict between the provisions of this chapter and general business licensing and regulation provisions, the specific shall prevail over the general, and the more stringent provision shall apply. 
Sec. 4-24. - License required. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall distribute, vend, sell, offer or keep for sale at retail or wholesale, deal or traffic in or for the purpose of evading any law or ordinance, give away any intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage or cause the same to be done without having procured a license or permit as provided in this chapter or without complying with all the provisions of this chapter and all statutes, ordinances and regulations of the state and city applicable thereto. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(2)) 
Sec. 4-25. - Classes of licenses. 
    There shall be the following classes of licenses which, when issued by the city clerk under the authority of the city council after payment of the fee specified in this article, shall permit the holder to sell, deal or traffic in intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 125.17, 125.25, 125.26, 125.28 and 125.51. 
(1)  Class A fermented malt beverage retailer's license. 
(2)  Class B fermented malt beverage retailer's license. 
(3)  Wholesaler's fermented malt beverage license. 
(4)  Temporary class B retailer's license. A single license may be issued to eligible organizations pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 125.26(6). 
(5)  Special wholesaler's fermented malt beverage license. 
(6)  Class C wine license. A class C license authorizes the retail sale of wine by the glass or in opened original container for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(7)  Operator's license. 
(8)  Retail class A liquor license. 
(9)  Retail class B liquor license. 
(10)  Class A liquor license for sales limited to cider. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(3); Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 2, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-26. - Limitation on number of licenses. 
(a)  Class B retail liquor licenses shall be limited as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 125.51(4). 
(b)  Class A retail liquor licenses shall be limited to a total number of 13 issued in the city. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(4); Ord. No. 2012-10-08-D, § 1, 10-9-2012) 
Sec. 4-27. - Application for licenses identified in section 4-25. 
(a)  Form of sworn application. All applications, except for operator's licenses, shall be made in writing on the form prescribed by the state department of revenue and shall be sworn to by the applicant as provided by Wis. Stats. § 887.01. 
(b)  Filing. The application shall be filed with the city clerk not less than 15 days before the next meeting of the committee of the whole. 
(c)  Contents of application. The premises shall be physically described on the application to include every room and storage space to be covered by the license, including all rooms not separated by a solid wall or joined by connecting entrances. 
(d)  Publication costs. Each application shall be accompanied by the cost of publication required by Wis. Stats. § 125.04(3)(g) and shall be published as therein prescribed. 
(e)  Council approval required. Unless otherwise designated, licenses required by this chapter shall be issued by the city clerk only with approval of the common council. Opportunity shall be given by the committee of the whole and the common council to any person to be heard for or against the granting of any license. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a); Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 3, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-28. - License fees. 
    The application for license hereunder shall be accompanied by a license fee in the amount established by the city council. Regardless of time of application, there shall be no proration of fees for wholesaler's fermented malt beverage licenses, special wholesaler's fermented malt beverage licenses, or temporary class B retailers' licenses. The fee for all other new licenses issued pursuant to this chapter, after July 1 of each year shall be prorated on the basis of the number of months or fractions thereof remaining in the licensing year. Fees for operator's licenses, which expire June 30 of even-numbered years, are pro-rated according to the schedule set by the city council. 
(Code 1993, § 12.16) 
Sec. 4-29. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  Notice of hearing. Each applicant shall be notified of the date and time the committee of the whole shall consider the application. Notification shall be deemed given upon hand delivery to the applicant or the mailing to the applicant's last known address. 
(b)  Effect of failure to appear. Failure to appear in person for the initial application will result in a negative recommendation. 
(c)  Review; recommendation. The committee of the whole shall, after interviewing the applicant or reviewing any other written documentation from the applicant, make recommendation to the common council to either grant or deny the license. 
(d)  Statement of denial. If the recommendation is to deny the application, a written statement of the reasons will be forwarded to the common council along with said recommendation. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a)1) 
Sec. 4-30. - Inspections; investigation. 
(a)  Inspection. The city clerk shall notify the chief of police, chief of the fire department and building inspector of the application. Each official shall inspect the application and the premises to determine whether the applicant and the premises sought to be licensed comply with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto. 
(b)  Report. These officials shall furnish to the committee of the whole and common council information derived from such investigation and a statement as to whether the applicant and the premises meet the requirements of the department for whom the officer is certifying. 
(c)  Applications for renewal. For all renewal applications, the police department shall report any and all major or minor violations of the licensed establishment as defined in this chapter. No recommendation shall be made by any official as to whether the application should be approved or denied. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a)2; Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 4, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-31. - Qualifications for licensure. 
    A license for a premises may be denied unless the applicant: 
(1)  Has been a resident of the state for at least 90 days prior to applying for such license; 
(2)  Is at least 21 years of age; 
(3)  Has successfully completed a responsible beverage server training course pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 125.04(5)(a)5; 
(4)  Provides documentary proof of his right to possession of the premises sought be to licensed upon request by the city; 
(5)  Provides proof under Wis. Stats. § 77.61(11) that he is the holder of a seller's permit or will be issued a seller's permit from the appropriate state agency; 
(6)  Does not have an arrest or conviction record of offenses that substantially relate to the circumstances of the licensed activity to include: 
a.  Any nonfelony alcohol-related conviction or pending charges within the last 12 months. 
b.  A history of nonfelony alcohol-related convictions as long as the most current conviction or arrest is within the last 24 months. 
c.  Any nonfelony drug related convictions or pending charges within the last 12 months. 
d.  Any nonfelony conviction or pending charges within the last 36 months which involve resisting arrest, battery to a police officer or obstructing justice in direct connection to activity at a licensed alcohol establishment. 
e.  Two or more nonfelony convictions or pending charges in the last 24 months for disorderly behavior type offenses if they occurred in direct connection to activity at a licensed alcohol establishment. 
f.  One or more felony convictions in the last ten years involving alcohol or drugs. 
g.  Any other arrest or conviction that is reasonably determined to be substantially related to the circumstances of the licensed activity. The reasons for such a determination shall be stated in writing with particularity by the governing body making said determination. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a)3; Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 5, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-32. - Delinquent obligations to city. 
(1)  No license authorized or required under this chapter shall be issued or renewed, unless the applicant shall have first settled any delinquent tax obligations, assessments or other fees owed to the city, as well as be brought into compliance with building, plumbing, electrical, zoning, health or fire codes at the time the license is to be granted or renewed. The city council shall not refuse to renew without first giving the applicant notice and a hearing as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 125.12. 
(2)  A delinquency on any obligation due and owing to the city and/or failure to remain in compliance with building, plumbing, electrical, zoning, health or fire codes shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of any license under this chapter. The city council shall not revoke or suspend a license without first giving the applicant notice and a hearing as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 125.12. 
(Code 1993, § 12.02(11)(c); Ord. No. 2011-07-08-D, § 1, 7-12-2011) 
Sec. 4-33. - Location restrictions. 
    No retail class A or B license shall be issued for a premises when: 
(1)  It is located less than 300 feet from any established public school, parochial school, hospital or church. Such distance shall be measured via the shortest route along the highway from the closest point of the boundary of such school, hospital or church to the closest entrance to such premises. 
(2)  It fails to conform to the sanitary, safety and health requirements of the state department of health and social services applicable to restaurants set forth in Wis. Stats. § 125.68(5). 
(3)  It is intended to be used to sell intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages by drive-thru window. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a)3.f) 
Sec. 4-34. - Issuance to agents. 
(a)  Prohibited. No class A or B license shall be issued to any person acting as agent for or in the employ of another. 
(b)  Exception. This restriction shall not apply class B licenses issued to a hotel or to a restaurant not a part of or located in or upon the premises of any mercantile establishment or to a bone fide club, society or lodge, labor union or ex-servicemen's post which has been in existence for not less than six months prior to the date of application or to a corporation as provided in Wis. Stats. § 125.04(6). 
(c)  Issuance to certain agents; qualifications. A class B license for a hotel, restaurant, club, society, lodge, labor union or ex-servicemen's post or corporation issued pursuant to this chapter may be taken in the name of an officer or manager who shall be personally responsible for compliance with all the terms and provisions of this chapter. Such officers or managers shall have resided in the state for at least 90 days prior to applying for such license. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(a)5) 
Sec. 4-35. - Incomplete or false applications. 
    All alcohol license and operator applications submitted which are incomplete or which contain false or misleading information shall be given a negative recommendation unless the committee finds strong mitigating circumstances. If an applicant receives a negative recommendation because of an incomplete or false application, or if the city council denies a license, the applicant must wait six months before resubmitting an application. The chief of police shall also have the discretionary authority to refer any false application to either circuit court or municipal court for prosecution of the applicant. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(c); Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 6, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-36. - Amendments to applications. 
    Whenever anything occurs to change any fact set out in the application of any license, such licensee shall file with the issuing authority a notice in writing of such change within ten days after the occurrence thereof. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(f)) 
Sec. 4-37. - Term; renewal applications. 
    All intoxicating liquor and fermented malt beverage licenses issued hereunder shall expire on June 30. All renewal applications for said licenses shall be submitted to the city clerk on or before April 20 of the year the license is sought to be renewed and shall be reviewed under the standards set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1993, § 12.03(5)(g); Ord. No. 2015-12-08-D, § 7, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 4-38. - Display of licenses. 
    Licenses for intoxicating liquors and fermented malt beverages shall be enclosed in a suitable wood or metal frame having a clear glass face and a substantial wood or metal back so that the whole is at all times displayed in a conspicuous place in the room where such business is carried on, except as provided by Wis. Stats. § 125.04(10). 
(Code 1993, § 12.02(9)) 
Sec. 4-39. - Demerit point system created. 
(a)  There is hereby established a point system for the purpose of guiding the city council on possible warnings, suspensions, non-renewals, or revocations of alcohol beverage licenses as well as operators licenses. The number of demerit points shall be assigned according to the type of violation. The system is intended to identify habitually troublesome liquor licensees who repeatedly violate state statutes and/or City of Tomah ordinances and to take consistent action against such licensees. 
(b)  Maintenance of demerit point document. After approval by the city council, the city clerk shall retain the demerit point document which describes violations, corresponding ordinance/law, and the demerit points to be assessed. This document may be amended by the city council and shall serve only as a guideline when a warning, suspension, non-renewal, or revocation of a license is being considered. 
(c)  Method of determination. In determining the accumulated points, the date of the violation is used as the basis for assigning the demerit points per incident.
