    Significant industrial user means a nongovernmental user which is required by Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 101 to file effluent reports for discharges made to the public sanitary sewer collection system, which includes, but is not limited to, any facility whose discharge is a volume greater than 10,000 gallons per day and contains any one or more of the industrial wastes or toxic and hazardous substances defined in Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 101, or whose discharge is less than 10,000 gallons per day but is subject to a pretreatment standard and which is classified as a major contributing industry or which has been notified in writing by the DNR that it is necessary to provide the agency with information concerning the concentration and quantity of pollutants discharged. 
    Slug load means any discharge of sewage or industrial wastewater, the concentration of any constituent of which or the quantity of flow of which exceeds instantaneously more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows of the user during normal operation. 
    Standard Methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water, Sewage, and Industrial Wastes published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation and is in compliance with federal regulations 40 CFR 136, Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures for Analysis of Pollutants, all as amended from time to time. Any reference to Standard Methods in this article also requires that the procedure used complies with Wis. Admin. Code chs. NR 218 and NR 219. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage, garbage and domestic wastewater other than noncontact cooling water from commercial and industrial users. 
    Stormwater runoff means the portion of the rainfall that is collected and drained into the storm sewers. 
    Surcharge means any user of the wastewater treatment facility whose discharge exceeds in one or more parameters (BOD, SS, TKN, phosphorus, etc.) of the concentration of normal domestic-strength wastewater for that parameter shall be subject to a surcharge. The amount of such surcharges shall reflect the costs incurred in removing the high-strength BOD or suspended solids, or other pollutants from the wastewater. A surcharge is in addition to all fixed and variable charges. 
    Suspended solids (SS) means solids that are visible and in suspension in the liquid, the quantity being determined by Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, latest edition. 
    Total Kjeldahl nitrogent (TKN) means the quantity of organic nitrogen and ammonia as determined in accordance with Standard Methods. 
    Treatment works means any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage, domestic sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature or necessary to recycle or reuse water at the most economical cost over the useful life of the works, including interceptor sewers, outfall sewers, sewage collection systems, individual systems, pumping, power and other equipment and their appurtenances; extensions, improvement, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof, elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply, such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities and any works, including site acquisitions of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process; the land that is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment; or any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste or industrial waste. 
    Unaltered water means water that is not changed chemically or physically as a result of use. 
    User charge means a sewer service charge. 
    Users means those residential, commercial, governmental, institutional and industrial establishments that are connected to the public sanitary sewer collection system. 
    Variable charge means a sewer use charge based upon the volume of normal domestic-strength wastewater to be transported and treated. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    Wastewater. See Sewage. 
    Wastewater treatment plant or facility means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    WPDES permit means the permit issued from time to time to the city by the state department of natural resources (DNR) that authorizes the city to discharge effluent to a watercourse in the state. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(1)) 
Sec. 46-127. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Discharges onto ground. No person shall place, deposit or permit to be deposited any sewage on the ground surface of any public or private property, within the jurisdiction of the agency. Noncontact cooling water and foundation drain water may be deposited on the ground provided that it does not cause a nuisance. 
(b)  Discharges into natural outlets. No person shall discharge any sewage except noncontact cooling waters to any natural outlet within the jurisdiction of the agency except where authorized by the state DNR. 
(c)  Septic tanks and similar facilities. Except as otherwise herein provided, no person shall construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  Tampering with sewer system. No unauthorized person shall alter, disturb or uncover any connections with or opening into any sanitary sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining written permission from the director. 
(e)  Water runoff connections. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, basement sump pumps or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain that in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a sanitary sewer. If such connections are found during an inspection by the director or his representative, correction shall be ordered. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or any other unaltered water to any sanitary sewer. 
(f)  Inflow or infiltration of unpolluted waters. All building sewers, both new and existing, shall be maintained in such condition as to prevent inflow or infiltration of unpolluted waters from the groundwater table, storm runoff or other sources. If, during an inspection, upon plugging the building sewer at or near its point of entry into the sanitary sewer, unpolluted water should be observed by the director or his representative to back up into the building being served, the building sewer shall be declared defective and correction shall be ordered. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(2), (4), (5)(a)) 
Sec. 46-128. - Toilet facilities required. 
(a)  Requirement and time for connection. The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, business, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the jurisdiction of the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is located a sanitary sewer, shall at the owner's expense install suitable toilet facilities and connect such facilities directly with the public sewer collection system in accordance with the provisions of this article within one year after the date of official notice by the department. No joint laterals may be used for two or more buildings under separate ownership. 
(b)  Charges and billing. After the expiration of one year, whether or not the property has been connected to the public system, the property owner or user shall be charged a quarterly bill based on the average usage for the property as determined by the department and based on public service commission guidelines for charging for unmetered service. The amount so charged shall be collected in accordance with the procedure in this article. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(2)) 
Sec. 46-129. - Private sewage disposal. 
(a)  When required; specifications. When a sanitary sewer is not available, the building sewer shall be connected to a private, individual sewage system complying with all related provisions of this article. The type, capacity, location and layout of a private, individual sewage disposal system shall comply with Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.20. 
(b)  Permit; fees. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage system, the owner shall obtain a written permit signed by the director. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the agency which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information deemed necessary by the director. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  Inspection. A permit for a private sewage system shall not become effective until the installation is completed and approved by the director. The director shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the director when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 48 hours of the receipt of notice by the director. 
(d)  Subsequent availability of city system. At such time as a sanitary sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage system, a direct connection at the building drain shall be made to the sanitary sewer in compliance with this article and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private or individual sewage facilities shall be abandoned in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.20. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(3)) 
Sec. 46-130. - Authority of inspectors. 
(a)  The director and other authorized employees of the agency bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurements, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The director or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other processes beyond that point, which have no direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sanitary sewers or wastewater treatment facilities. 
(b)  The director and other authorized employees of the agency bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage collection system of treatment works. All entry and subsequent work, if any, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of this article. 
(c)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the director or authorized employees of the agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner. The owner shall be held harmless for injury or death to the agency employees with the agency indemnifying the owner against loss or damage to its property by agency employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the owner which grow out of the inspection, gauging or sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the owner to maintain safe conditions. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(11)) 
Secs. 46-131-46-158. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 46-159. - Separate sewers required. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot, and no individual sewage system is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway. The building sewer from the front building may be extended in such cases to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. In all other cases, no joint laterals will be allowed. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the director to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(4)(d), (e)) 
Sec. 46-160. - Permits. 
(a)  Classes of permits. There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  Establishments producing only domestic wastewaters (including residences, institutions, public facilities and commercial establishments); and 
(2)  Establishments producing industrial wastewater. 
(b)  Application for permit; indemnification; fees. The owner or his representative shall make application on a special form furnished by the agency. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the director or building inspector. The permit application shall include the owner's indemnification of the agency from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. The permit and inspection fee shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  Inspection and connection. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the director when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the sanitary sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the director or his representative. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(4)(a), (b), (j)) 
Sec. 46-161. - Costs of construction. 
    All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(4)(c)) 
Sec. 46-162. - Excavations. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to minimize the hazard to public welfare and safety. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the agency. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(4)(k)) 
Sec. 46-163. - Construction specifications. 
(a)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.20, except that bituminous fiber pipe shall not be allowed. 
(b)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the sanitary sewer, sewage carried by such a building drain shall be lifted and discharged to the building sewer by facilities conforming to Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.11(3). 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(4)(f), (g)) 
Secs. 46-164-46-194. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION COSTS 

Sec. 46-195. - Payment methods. 
    All sanitary sewer extensions within the city shall be extended on either a special assessment or cost advancement basis. 
(Code 1993, § 13.11) 
Sec. 46-196. - Special assessments. 
(a)  When applicable. Sanitary sewer extensions shall be financed by special assessments when deemed advisable by the council. In general the special assessment method shall be used for main extensions to service areas in immediate need of service or which are deemed likely to develop and need service within ten years. All special assessments shall be levied in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.60 and this division. 
(b)  Front foot rates. Special assessments shall be determined according to benefits and levied on a front foot basis. The amount levied for each front foot of benefiting abutting property on each side of the street shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  The total estimated apportionable costs of the extension, including legal services, finance carrying charges, engineering, inspection, grading and the necessary street resurfacing and other direct and indirect costs, shall be determined. Such amount shall be divided by the total number of assessable front foot of property served by the main. 
(2)  The following items will be considered unapportionable costs as determined by an engineer hired by the public works and utilities commission: sewer mains in excess of eight feet in diameter, excavation greater than ten feet, sewage lift stations when the station provided is necessary for or of benefit to the general public or utility or when such facility is to serve a large geographic area as a separate and entire drainage basin. Prior to the public hearing for any project involving sewage lift stations, the public works and utilities commission shall determine whether or not the facilities are apportionable. 
(3)  The city council may annually by resolution determine the amount to be levied for each front foot of benefiting abutting property on each side of the street on the basis of previous experience and estimated costs for the coming construction year. 
(c)  Single frontage lots. The special assessment on lots that abut on only one public street shall be determined by multiplying the total number of front footage by the special assessment charge per foot. 
(d)  Corner lots. The special assessment on corner lots shall be made on the basis of the footage on the short side even though the hookup might be on the long side. However, if the long side exceeds 150 feet, the footage in excess of 150 feet shall also be assessed on foot rate basis. A corner lot shall be defined as a lot with adjacent sides fronting on streets with the frontage on the two streets equal to approximately 50 percent of the perimeter of the lot or a method approved by the city council at a public hearing. 
(e)  Irregular lots. The special assessment on irregular lots shall be based on a method approved by the city council at the public hearing. 
(f)  M-1, M-2 and M-3 districts. Notwithstanding the provisions contained in this section, the owner of property zoned M-1, M-2 and M-3 shall be responsible for paying 75 percent of the assessment at the time of hookup and the city shall be responsible for 25 percent of the assessment. 
(Code 1993, § 13.12) 
Sec. 46-197. - Cost advancement. 
    Sanitary sewer extensions shall be financed by cost advancements when deemed advisable by the council. In general the cost advancement method shall be used only when applications are made for sanitary sewer service that would require the extensions or mains through sparsely occupied areas to serve such applicants or through areas that in the judgment of the council are unlikely to develop extensively within the next ten years. Where extensions are authorized on a cost advancement basis, the procedure shall be as follows: 
(1)  The applicant shall deposit with the city treasurer a sum equal to the estimated total amount that would have been assessed to all property that would have been assessed under section 46-196. 
(2)  Such deposit shall be made before construction is started or contracted. If the actual apportionable cost is less than the amount deposited, the excess of the deposit over the cost shall be refunded to the applicant within 30 days after payment for the completed project. If the apportionable cost exceeds the deposit, the applicant shall pay the deficiency prior to the granting of sanitary sewer service. 
(3)  When additional customers are connected to a sanitary sewer main that was originally financed in part by customers, the city shall require a contribution from each new customer in an amount necessary to equalize the average contribution. When the amount of customer contribution computed is less than would have been assessed under section 46-196, the applicant for service shall pay an amount equivalent to the assessment. This amount shall then be refunded pro rata to all contributors along the extension whose remaining contribution still exceeds what would have been assessed under section 46-196. 
(4)  When refunds have reduced the contribution of any contributor to the applicable assessment per front foot, no further refund will be made to that individual. After all refunds have been made, the remaining premises that may connect will be charged at the rate per front foot established for the extension. 
(5)  All refunds pertaining to connection charges collected by the city shall be paid to the applicant or his assigns or heirs, unless specifically provided otherwise in writing. 
(6)  When an extension beyond an existing extension is required to serve a new customer and the cost for a customer exceeds the average remaining contribution in the original extension, then the new extension will be considered as an entirely new project without refunds or any other connection to the original extension. 
(7)  When customers connect to a sanitary sewer main laid at city expense, there shall be a contribution of an amount equivalent to the applicable assessment determined in section 46-196. 
(8)  The development period during which refunds shall be made will be limited to 20 years. 
(Code 1993, § 13.13) 
Secs. 46-198-46-217. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INDUSTRIAL WASTE GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-218. - Protection of sewer system. 
    The agency reserves the right to refuse or limit the amount or character of any or all industrial wastewaters from an industry or combination of industries as may be necessary to ensure adequate treatment and proper operation of the public sewer collection system. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(b)) 
Sec. 46-219. - Applicability of state rules and regulations. 
    No statement contained in this subsection shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(p)) 
Sec. 46-220. - Liability for damages. 
    If a discharge causes the city to incur additional expenses, the expenses shall be billed to the discharger. If a user discharges wastewaters that contain substances that cause blockage of the city's sewers, the discharger will be billed for the cost of restoring services and repairing damage to other property. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(n)) 
Sec. 46-221. - Maintenance and special agreements. 
    A maintenance agreement may be required between the city and any discharger of the types of wastes enumerated in this division. No statement contained in this subsection shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the agency and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the agency for treatment subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern, provided the agreement is not in conflict with the intent or rates established by this article or with Wisconsin Administrative Code requirements. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(o)) 
Sec. 46-222. - Authority of director. 
(a)  Permission required. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the substances, materials, fluids or solids, specifically described in this division or that may harm sanitary sewers, sewage treatment processes and equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or constitute a nuisance, without the specific written permission of the director. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of wastes, the director will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sanitary sewers, materials of construction of the sanitary sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant and other pertinent factors. 
(b)  Discharge restrictions. If any sewage is discharged or proposed to be discharged to the public sewer collection system which contains the substances or possesses the characteristics enumerated in this division and, in the judgment of the director, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage treatment works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director may in writing: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition prior to discharge to the sanitary sewers; 
(3)  Require flow equalization of the rate of discharge; or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by sewer charges under the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Submission of plans and specifications. If the director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, plans and specifications shall be submitted to the city and, if applicable, the DNR for review and approval. 
(d)  Termination of permission. The director's permission, if given, is subject to termination at any time upon written notice. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(d)-(f)) 
Sec. 46-223. - Specific substances. 
    The substances prohibited without the director's express permission as provided in this division include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive fluid or solid or wastes that may create a fire or explosion hazard in the publicly owned treatment works. 
(2)  Any fluids or solids containing toxic or poisonous elements in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other elements, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(3)  Any fluids or solids having corrosive properties capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the sewage treatment plant. 
(4)  Fluid or solid substances in quantities or of such size or nature as to cause obstruction to the flow in sanitary sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to, unground garbage, ashes, cinders, clay, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups or milk containers, either whole or ground by garbage grinders, or any soluble substance that would create a viscosity of liquid greater than 1.1 in any portion of the treatment works. 
(5)  Any fluid having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit, 65 degrees Celsius. 
(6)  Any liquid containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 25 mg/l on a daily average basis or 100 mg/l on an instantaneous basis or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 degrees Fahrenheit and 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(7)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded or solid material or insoluble substance having any dimension greater than one-half inch. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horse power or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the director. 
(8)  Any fluid or solid containing chromium, copper, zinc, cyanide and similar objectionable or toxic substances which exceed the limits which are established for such materials. Unless more restrictive limits are established by a state or federal regulatory agency having jurisdiction, the following concentrations in milligrams per liter (mg/l) shall not be exceeded on a grab sample basis: 
Arsenic 0.50 Barium 4.00 Cadmium 0.01 Chromium 0.60 Copper 1.00 Cyanide 0.05 Lead 0.200 Mercury 0.002 Nickel 2.000 Selenium 0.004 Silver 0.100 Zinc 1.000  
Major contributing industries shall comply with the limits established in this section or with the pretreatment requirements for removal or reduction of incompatible pollutants required for discharges to publicly owned treatment works set forth for the applicable point source category or subcategory in Wis. Admin. Code, chs. NR 221 through NR 299, whichever is more stringent. 
(9)  Any fluid or solid containing phenols or other taste- or odor-producing substances in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the director as necessary or as are established by the state, federal or other public agencies having jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. Unless other limits are established by a state or federal regulatory agency having jurisdiction, the concentration of phenol shall not exceed 0.005 mg/l on an instantaneous basis. 
(10)  Any waste containing more than 100 mg/l of antiseptic substances. 
(11)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by state or federal regulations. 
(12)  Any liquids or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0 or in excess of 9.0 on a daily average basis or lower than 5.0 or in excess of 10.0 on an instantaneous basis. 
(13)  Materials that exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, clays, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids detrimental to the treatment processes. 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions) or excessive odors. 
c.  Unusual chemical oxygen demand or chlorine requirements in quantities in excess of that found in domestic sewage. 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined. 
(14)  BOD 5 in excess of 5,000 mg/l on an instantaneous basis or 500 mg/l on an average daily (workday) basis. 
(15)  Total solids in excess of 20,000 mg/l on an instantaneous basis or 2,000 mg/l on an average daily (workday) basis. 
(16)  Suspended solids in excess of 10,000 mg/l on an instantaneous basis or 1,000 mg/l on an average daily (workday) basis. 
(17)  Fluids or solids containing substances which are not amenable to treatment by the sewage treatment processes employed or are untreatable to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(d)) 
Sec. 46-224. - Separators and interceptors. 
    Grease and oil separators and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquids containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable fluid, sand or other harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors and separators shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All separators and interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the DNR or DILHR and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory condition and effectively operated by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(g), (h)) 
Sec. 46-225. - Sampling, testing, and reporting. 
(a)  Report due date. All significant industrial users shall report the characteristics of their discharges by February 1 of each year for the preceding calendar year. 
(b)  Sampling and flow measurement manhole. All significant industrial users shall install a single suitable sampling and flow measurement manhole in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.04(4)(l). The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(c)  Special control manhole. All major contributing industries shall install a single special control manhole. The special control manhole shall consist of a manhole on the discharge line with a flow rate measuring device and a separate structure for housing recording instruments and an automatic proportional sampler. The sampler shall automatically (in proportion to volume) collect samples of the waste. The agency shall record volume and operate the automatic sampler on such occasions as deemed necessary to develop a basis for user charges at the owner's expense. The owner shall design, construct, operate and maintain the special control manhole at his expense. The location and access to the special control manhole shall be as provided for in Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.04(4)(e). The special control manhole shall be approved by the department of natural resources and the agency prior to installation. Special control manholes may be required by the agency should the industrial wastewater contain a toxic or deleterious fluid or solid not reflected by volume, BOD 5 , suspended solids or ammonia nitrogen plus organic nitrogen, or phosphorus. 
(d)  Standards for testing and analyses. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of fluids and solids to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater", published by the American Public Health Association, by a certified or registered lab. The control manhole shall be considered to be the most representative location in the sewage flow system of the premises. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(5)(i)-(m)) 
Secs. 46-226-46-243. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HOLDING AND SEPTIC TANK WASTES 

Sec. 46-244. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person or licensed disposer using or permitting the use of the city's sewerage system or a public sewerage system for a use for which a permit may be issued under this division without first obtaining a permit, or continuing use after notice of revocation of a permit, shall forfeit to the city the sum of $1,000.00 for each violation. Such forfeiture shall be recoverable by the city in a civil action brought by the city council in the name of the city and paid into the general funds of the city for the benefit of the city. In addition, such person or licensed disposer shall pay to the city any damages, costs or expenses incurred by the city in connection with such unpermitted use. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)) 
Sec. 46-245. - Discharge into community sewers. 
    No person, including a licensed disposer, shall discharge any holding tank wastes, or any other liquid, gaseous or solid wastes directly into a manhole or other opening in a public sewer, except city-owned dumping stations. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(a)) 
Sec. 46-246. - Discharge into city's treatment facilities. 
(a)  Holding or septic tank wastes; industrial waste. Discharge of holding tank or septic tank wastes may be allowed only at the city wastewater treatment plant in such manner and at such place as may be designated by the director. Industrial wastes, or any other liquid, gaseous or solid wastes not detrimental to the city's wastewater treatment plant, may be discharged at such plant in a manner designated by the director when, in his judgment, the waste is of such unusual character or strength that rapid discharge into the sewerage system would have detrimental effects on the wastewater facilities. 
(b)  Licensed disposers. Discharges of holding tank or septic tank wastes by a licensed disposer shall be allowed at the city's wastewater treatment plant only in such manner and at such place as may be designated by the director and subject to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(b)) 
Sec. 46-247. - Limitations. 
(a)  Any holding tank waste or other wastes permitted to be discharged shall be of domestic origin, or contain compatible pollutants only. 
(b)  The person or licensed disposer making the discharge under this section shall comply with the provisions of any and all applicable rules and regulations; and shall comply with this article. 
(c)  Without intending to limit the application of other provisions of this article, such person or licensed disposer shall not deposit or drain any gasoline, oil, acid, alkali, grease, rags, volatile or flammable liquids, or other deleterious substances into any manhole or community sewer, or into the city's wastewater facility; nor shall such person or licensed disposer allow any grease, earth, sand or other solid materials to pass into any part of the sewerage system; nor shall such person or licensed disposer discharge any liquid, gaseous or solid wastes determined by the director to be detrimental to the sewerage system or to the city's employees or to the process of sewage treatment. 
(d)  No discharges shall be permitted directly into any of the city's interceptor sewers, unless the director so authorizes. 
(e)  If the city's sewerage system can accept some, but not all, of the holding/septic tank wastes offered for disposal, the director may accept such waste which is generated within the geographic boundaries of the city before accepting such wastes which are generated outside of the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(c)) 
Sec. 46-248. - Permit required; application. 
    No discharge shall be made under this division unless the person or licensed disposer making the discharge has been issued a permit therefor. All applications for a permit shall be in writing; shall contain such information as the director deems appropriate; and shall be submitted to the director no later than September 1 of each year. No permit once issued shall be assignable or transferable by the person receiving the same. All such permits shall be valid for a period of one year, beginning on October 1, and expiring on September 30 of each year. No holder of any permit shall acquire any vested right or privilege by reason thereof. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(d)) 
Sec. 46-249. - Minimum permitting requirements. 
    If the director determines to issue a permit, such permit may be issued upon such terms and conditions as the director may provide; and any such permit shall provide at a minimum the following: 
(1)  The permit shall be conditioned upon the holder's faithful compliance with the provisions of the city's sewer use regulations. 
(2)  The agreement of the holder thereof to indemnify the city from and against any and all liability for injury or damage arising out of or related to the activities of the holder in exercising the rights granted. The director may require the holder of such permit to post a bond written by a bonding company licensed to transact business in the state, to guarantee performance of the holder thereunder. 
(3)  The agreement of the holder thereof to have in full force and effect sufficient worker's compensation insurance, public liability and property damage insurance, in such amounts as the director may reasonably require. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(d)) 
Sec. 46-250. - Annual fee. 
    In the event the director issues a permit, the public works department may require the applicant to pay an annual fee in such reasonable amount as it may determine as a condition precedent to the issuance of such permit. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(d)) 
Sec. 46-251. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued hereunder shall be revocable by the city council or the director summarily for violation of the terms and conditions thereof. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(d)) 
Sec. 46-252. - Additional permit requirements for licensed disposers. 
(a)  Additional permit requirements. The permit issued to the licensed disposer hereunder shall also provide that: 
(1)  The city may accept holding tank or septic tank wastes at any time during the year during normal working hours; and reserves the right to reject and refuse acceptance under the circumstances set forth in this section. 
(2)  The city shall have the right to reject and refuse to accept holding tank wastes from the licensed disposer if: 
a.  Treatment of the waste would cause the city sewerage system to exceed its operating design capacity or to violate any applicable effluent limitations or standard water quality standards or any other legally applicable requirements, including court orders or state or federal statutes, rules, regulations or orders; 
b.  The waste is not compatible with the city's sewerage system; 
c.  The licensed disposer has not applied for and received a permit hereunder to dispose of the waste in the city's sewerage system or the licensed disposer fails to comply with the permit so issued; or 
d.  The licensed disposer fails to comply with waste disposal rules promulgated by the city from time to time or fails to pay the appropriate sewer service charges in a timely manner. 
(b)  Additional terms and conditions permissible. The director may impose reasonable terms and conditions for holding tank waste disposal into the wastewater treatment plant relating to the following: 
(1)  Specific quantities, locations, times and methods for discharge of such wastes into the city's sewerage system; 
(2)  Requirement to report the source and amount of such wastes placed in the city's sewerage system; and 
(3)  Requirements that the licensed disposer analyze representative samples of the waste placed in the city sewerage system in order to determine the characteristics of the waste and the compatibility of the waste with the city's sewerage system. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(6)(e)) 
Secs. 46-253-46-282. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LATERAL CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 46-283. - Permit required; fee. 
    No lateral connection shall be made to any main sewer, unless a permit is obtained from the plumbing inspector. The fee for such connection shall be determined from time to time by resolution of the council. Fees shall be determined on the basis of the average previous cost and estimated future costs. 
(Code 1993, § 13.14) 
Sec. 46-284. - Connection of annexed properties; charge. 
    The owners of any property annexed to the city lying adjacent to any sewer main installed prior to the annexation proceedings shall at the time of connection to the sewer main obtain a permit to connect to the sewer system from the plumbing inspector and pay the city treasurer the connection charge required by this division. The connection charge shall be equal to the assessment previously levied on each lot, part of lot or parcel of land fronting or abutting the sewer main and benefiting thereby and shall be due and payable at the time of the connection thereto. 
(Code 1993, § 13.15) 
Sec. 46-285. - Sewer pipe materials. 
    All sewer main and sewer lateral pipe used in the city sewer system and upon property of the city shall be equal to ASMD-30-34, SDR 35. 
(Code 1993, § 13.16) 
Sec. 46-286. - Floor drain closing. 
    All floor drains or low level openings to the sewer system shall be protected with backwater valves, plugs or other similar devices to prevent wastes from entering premises whenever there is an obstruction or an excessive flow in the sewer main. 
(Code 1993, § 13.17) 
Secs. 46-287-46-305. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

Sec. 46-306. - Usage-based charges. 
    The city shall charge all users of the sanitary sewer collection system and wastewater treatment works based on the quantity and quality of their wastewater and the size of water meters serving the user. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)) 
Sec. 46-307. - Intent. 
    The user charge system is intended to result in the distribution of the cost of amortization of the city's capital cost, sinking fund costs for equipment replacement and the cost of operation and maintenance of treatment works to each user class in proportion to such class's contribution to the total loading by all users of the treatment works. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(a)) 
Sec. 46-308. - Computation of costs. 
(a)  Separately computed. The costs of amortization of the city's capital cost and the cost of operation and maintenance shall be computed separately. 
(b)  Operation and maintenance costs. The costs of operation and maintenance upon which user charges shall be based are the costs of operation and maintenance of the previous year plus an amount to be equal to the estimated additional costs for the following year. The expected costs for the replacement of equipment during the life of the plant are used to compute the amount that must be deposited annually to have this money available at the time of replacement. 
(c)  Capital cost and bonds. Charges for recovery of the city's portion of capital cost expenditures and the retirement of bonds shall be computed using the formulas as established in this article. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(a), (b)) 
Sec. 46-309. - Computation of user charges. 
(a)  The volume, BOD 5 , suspended solids, ammonia, and phosphorus concentrations shall be used as the basis for each user's contribution to ensure a proportional distribution of costs to each. 
(b)  The characteristic of domestic wastewater from residential users will be utilized as the basis for computation of charges for nonresidential users. Nonresidential users shall pay, as a minimum, the same rate per volume as that paid by residential users. Industrial or commercial users with wastes with strengths above the level of domestic wastewater shall pay a surcharge or additional charge based upon the formula established in this article to cover the costs of treating such wastes. 
(c)  Each user which discharges any toxic pollutants that cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge of the treatment works as determined by the agency shall pay for such increased costs. 
(d)  The costs of operation and maintenance for all flow not directly attributable to users (e.g., infiltration and inflow) shall be distributed among all users on the basis of the flow volume of users, except where the infiltration/inflow is a measurable quantity attributable to a single user, such as that in the area of the Veteran's Administration Hospital complex. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(c)-(e), (g)) 
Sec. 46-310. - Periodic review. 
    The agency shall review biannually or more often the wastewater contribution of users and user classes, the amortization of city capital costs for the coming year, the total cost of operation and maintenance of treatment facility portion of the treatment works and its system of user charges to accomplish the following: 
(1)  Maintain the proportional distribution of operation and maintenance costs among users and user classes. 
(2)  Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance costs necessary for the proper operation and maintenance of the treatment works. 
(3)  Apply excess revenues collected from the previous year to the cost of operation and maintenance of next year's revenues or to a reserve fund. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(f)) 
Sec. 46-311. - Fixed charge basis. 
(a)  A fixed charge per billing period will be charged to each user on the basis of meter size. This charge will be independent of wastewater characteristics and will be assessed equally among users with the same meter size. In the event that a user has unmetered service, this charge will be assessed on the basis of flow equivalency to a typical residential user (five-eighths-inch meter) multiplied by 1.5. 
(b)  Fixed charges shall be calculated as follows: 
(1)  Fixed charges are calculated to recover a portion of the costs of amortization of the city's capital costs. The city will determine a set charge per equivalent meter. The remaining costs to be paid by user charges will be distributed on a variable charge basis. The fixed charge rate will be subject to periodic review by the city. 
(2)  The fixed charge for a user with a five-eighths-inch or three-fourths-inch meter is the established fixed rate per equivalent meter. Users with larger than a five-eighths-inch or three-fourths-inch meter will be charged according to the number of equivalent meters that the user's meter represents. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(h), (i)) 
Sec. 46-312. - Variable charge basis. 
    The variable charge portion of the user charge system covers the portion of the cost of amortization of the city's capital costs not distributed to fixed costs, cost for the equipment replacement sinking fund, and costs for the operation and maintenance of the wastewater treatment facility and collection system. Charges shall be based upon the following measurements: 
(1)  Residential users. Cubic feet of liquid discharged as established by city water meter readings, with credit being given for outside water usage not discharged to sewer only if an additional meter is purchased and installed by the customer prior to usage. 
(2)  Industrial, commercial and public users. Cubic feet of liquid discharged since the previous billing period as determined by city water meter readings or by meters approved pursuant to this article. 
(3)  The Veteran's Administration (VA) Hospital. The cubic feet of liquid discharged in the preceding measurement period as determined by representative recordings of the actual wastewater discharged at the VA Hospital. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(j)) 
Sec. 46-313. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Private water supply. If any user wishes to utilize a private water supply, he shall obtain permission from the director and shall install at his own expense at the source of supply a water meter approved by the director. 
(b)  Commercial or industrial user separating waters. If any commercial or industrial user wishes to separate waters that are not discharged to the sanitary sewer system from those which are so discharged, he shall obtain permission from the director and shall install at his own expense a water meter approved by the director. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(j)) 
Sec. 46-314. - Variable charge calculation. 
    The variable charge portion of the user charge system shall be computed as follows: 
(1)  The charges for the variable portion of the user charge system for the wastewater treatment works shall be computed according to the following formula: 
C = V u C u = V u (C t /V t ) 
Where: 
C = A user's charge for operation and maintenance costs for a billing period. 
C t = Total operation and maintenance costs and other costs distributed on a variable charge basis per year, reduced by the amount of any yearly surcharges computed under subsection (2) of this section. 
C u = Variable charge for one unit of volume. 
V u = Volume contribution from a user per billing period. 
V t = Total volume contribution from all users per year. 
(2)  Where the strength of the wastewater exceeds that of domestic wastewater, a surcharge shall be added as follows: 
C;sub§\sub; = 8.34V u [B c (B) + S c (S) + N c (N) + P c (P)] 
Where: 
C;sub§\sub; = A surcharge for wastewaters of excessive strength. 
B c = Variable charge cost for treatment of a pound of five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD 5 ). 
B = Concentration of five-day biochemical oxygen demand from a user above that of domestic wastewater, expressed in mg/l. 
S c = Variable charge cost for treatment of a pound of suspended solids. 
S = Concentration of suspended solids from a user above that of domestic wastewater, expressed in mg/l. 
N c = Variable charge cost for treatment of a pound of ammonia nitrogen plus organic nitrogen. 
N = Concentration of ammonia nitrogen plus organic nitrogen from a user above that of domestic wastewater, expressed as mg/l. 
P c = Variable charge cost for treatment of a pound of phosphorus. 
P = Concentration of total phosphorus from a user above that of domestic wastewater, expressed in mg/l. 
V u = Volume contribution from a user per billing period, expressed in millions of gallons. 
(3)  If one or more concentrations are less than those in domestic wastewater, they shall be dropped from the calculation rather than being considered as credit. 
(4)  The method of calculation of variable user charges shall consist of the following distinct steps: 
a.  Distribution of total variable charge costs to establish a yearly unit treatment cost per gallon or per cubic foot, per pound of BOD 5 , per pound of suspended solids, per pound of ammonia nitrogen plus total nitrogen, and per pound of phosphorus. 
b.  Computation of surcharges for above normal strength domestic users based upon actual measurements according to the formula defined in this section. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(k)) 
Sec. 46-315. - Charges for discharge to city's treatment system. 
    Charges for holding tank/septic tank and other wastes discharged to the city's treatment system at city-owned dumping stations or receiving stations will be calculated in a manner similar to the variable charges and surcharges described in this division. Charges will be calculated based on the amount of wastes discharged plus additional surcharges for concentrations of compatible pollutants above those set for domestic/normal strength wastewater. The city may calculate a fixed rate per volume for septic and holding tank wastes based on typical concentrations of compatible pollutants in these wastes. Any wastes received by the city containing incompatible pollutants (i.e., gas recovery system wastewater containing BTEX) may be subject to additional charges based on acceptable levels of these contaminants. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(7)(l)) 
Sec. 46-316. - Disposition of revenue. 
    The amounts received from the collection of sewer service charges shall be credited to the sanitary sewerage account that shall show all receipts and expenditures of the sewerage system. Charges collected for replacement expenses shall be credited to a segregated, nonlapsing replacement account. These funds are to be used exclusively for replacement. When appropriated by the city council, the credits to the sanitary sewerage account shall be available for the payment of the requirements for operation, maintenance, repairs, and depreciation of the sewerage system consistent with 40 CFR 35.929. Any surplus in the account outside the purview of 40 CFR 35.929 shall be available for payment of principal and interest of obligations issued and outstanding or which may be issued to provide funds for the expenses for additions and improvements and other necessary disbursements or indebtedness. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(8)(g)) 
Secs. 46-317-46-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - BILLING AND PAYMENT 

Sec. 46-336. - Computation; billing form. 
(a)  Sewer use charges that are to be assessed to users shall be computed and approved by the city council according to the rates and methodology presented in this article. 
(b)  Each customer's bill shall identify the rate and that portion of the user charges that are attributable to operation and maintenance of the treatment works and that portion dedicated to other costs of providing wastewater treatment services, such as the retirement of bonds. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(8)(a), (b)) 
Sec. 46-337. - Billing cycle; due date; late payment fees. 
    Billing intervals shall be established by the council, but not less frequently than quarterly. Bills are due and payable when rendered. Delinquent bills shall be charged a late payment penalty equal to the penalty rate set by the public service commission. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(8)(c)) 
Sec. 46-338. - Obligation for payment. 
    The obligation for payment of sewer service charges, application fees, connection fees or other charges due the city shall be a joint and several obligation of the user and property owner, where the user and property owner are not the same person. To the end that there may be attempts at avoidance of payment of such charges and fees by nonproperty-owner users, and to overcome the same, the city may send the bill for such a user in care of the property owner. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(8)(e)) 
Sec. 46-339. - Remedies for failure to make payment. 
(a)  Suit. Sewer service charges, application fees, connection fees or other charges due from any person or user shall be deemed to be a debt due to the city from that person or user. If sewer use charges, application fees, connection fees, or other charges are not paid when due, the city may commence an action in a court of competent jurisdiction and recover from such persons or users the amount of charges or fees, and damages, if any, sustained by the city as a result of such failure to pay, together with attorney's fees incurred in collecting the sums, court costs and such other costs and expenses as may be allowed by law. 
(b)  Lien on property. As an alternative to commencing an action in court for collection, the city council may direct that unpaid sewer service charges, application fees, connection fees, or other charges due from any person or user, shall be collected on tax rolls and shall be a lien upon the property, due before transfer of ownership, and not transferable to new owners. 
(c)  Remedies cumulative. All remedies provided for in this section are distinct and cumulative to any other right or remedy under any other provisions of the Code or afforded by law or equity and may be exercised by the city concurrently, independently, or successively. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(8)(d), (f)) 
Secs. 46-340-46-366. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - VIOLATIONS-PUBLIC NUISANCE 

Sec. 46-367. - Violations as public nuisance. 
    A violation of any provisions of this article, other than the failure to pay sewer service charges or other fees or costs due under this article, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(a)) 
Sec. 46-368. - Damage to city property. 
    No person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure or equipment that is a part of the city's sewerage system. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(b)) 
Sec. 46-369. - Liability to city. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, attorney's fees, costs, engineering fees, loss, or damage occasioned by reason of such violation that the city may suffer as a result thereof. Without intending to limit the generality of the foregoing, the city council shall have the right of recovery from all such persons any expense incurred by the city for the repair or replacement of any part of the public sewerage system damaged in any manner by any person by the performance of any work under its control, or by any negligent acts. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(l)) 
Sec. 46-370. - Enforcement. 
    The city council shall have the right to enforce the provisions of this article and shall make periodic inspections and inspections upon complaint to ensure that such provisions are not violated. No action shall be taken under article to abate a public nuisance unless the director shall have inspected or caused to be inspected the premises where the nuisance is alleged to exist and shall have satisfied itself that a nuisance does in fact exist. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(c)) 
Sec. 46-371. - Summary abatement. 
    If the city council determines that a public nuisance exists within the city and that there is a great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, or welfare, the city council may cause the same to be abated and charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant, or person causing, permitting, or maintaining the nuisance, as the case may be. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(d)) 
Sec. 46-372. - Abatement after notice. 
    If the city council determines that public nuisance exists on the private premises but that the nature of such nuisance is not such as to present great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, or welfare, the city council shall serve notice to the person causing or maintaining the nuisance to remove the same within ten days. If such nuisance is not removed within such ten days, the city council may cause the nuisances to be removed as provided in this division or elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(e)) 
Sec. 46-373. - Remedy not exclusive. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the city or its officials in accordance with the laws of the state. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(f)) 
Sec. 46-374. - Entry for abatement. 
    Except when necessary for summary abatement, the city shall not use force to obtain access to private property to abate a public nuisance, but shall request permission to enter upon private property if such premises are occupied, and, if such permission is denied, may apply to any court having jurisdiction for an order assisting the abatement of public nuisance. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(g)) 
Sec. 46-375. - Costs of abatement. 
    In addition to any other penalty imposed by this article for the erection, contrivance, creating, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the city shall be considered as a debt and shall be collected from the owner, occupant, or person causing, permitting, or maintaining the nuisance, and such cost shall be assessed against the real estate of such person as a special charge. For purposes hereof, costs shall include but not be limited to reasonable attorney's fees and court costs incurred. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(h)) 
Sec. 46-376. - Continuing violations. 
    Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the notice time limit provided shall forfeit not less than $500.00 or more than $1,000.00 together with the costs of prosecution. In default of payment of such forfeiture and costs, the violator shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not to exceed 30 days. Each day in which any violation is continued beyond the notice time limit shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(i)) 
Sec. 46-377. - Accidental discharge. 
    Any person found to be responsible for accidentally allowing a deleterious discharge into the public sewerage system which causes damage to the sewerage system or a receiving body of water (e.g., lake, river, stream, etc.) shall, in addition to the forfeitures provided for in this division, pay any fines, fees or damages as may be levied by other governmental authorities having appropriate jurisdiction. Any person responsible for an accidental discharge that may have a detrimental impact on the sewerage system shall immediately report the nature and amount of the discharge to the city. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(9)(j)) 
Secs. 46-378-46-397. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - APPEAL 

Sec. 46-398. - Review of administrative determinations. 
    Any person having a substantial interest which is adversely affected by an administrative determination of the director, the city engineer or the city council or any agent thereof, which determination relates to the subject matter of this article, may have such determination reviewed or provided for herein. Only administrative determinations described in Wis. Stats. § 68.02 are subject to review under this division. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, any determinations involving sewer service charges (or any component thereof), application fees, connection fees, or any other fees or costs due under this article are not subject to review hereunder. Further, any determinations involving the levying and assessment of special assessments or any of the determinations described in Wis. Stats. § 68.03 are not subject to review hereunder. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(a)) 
Sec. 46-399. - Request for review. 
    A person satisfying the requirements of this division shall first make a written request to the city council for a review of the administrative determination, which request shall be submitted to the city clerk within 15 days following the determination in question. The request shall be in writing, shall state the name and address of the person seeking the review, shall describe the circumstances surrounding the determination, and shall state the grounds upon which such person contends that the determination should be modified or reversed. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(b)) 
Sec. 46-400. - Hearing. 
    Upon receipt of a request for review, the person seeking the review shall have a hearing before the city council; provided the provisions of this division are satisfied. The hearing shall be held at a time and place determined by the city council, within 45 days from the date of receipt of the request. The council shall notify such person, by mail or personal service, at least ten days before such hearing of the time and place of the hearing. Except as otherwise provided for herein, the hearing shall be conducted in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 68.11(2). 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(c)) 
Sec. 46-401. - Review fee. 
    Any written request for review shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable review fee in the amount established by the city council. In the event the person seeking review desires the hearing proceedings to be taken by stenographer or by a recording device, the expense thereof shall be paid by the person seeking the review. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(d)) 
Sec. 46-402. - Decision; appeal. 
    Within 30 days of completion of the hearing under section 46-400 and the filing of briefs, if any, the city shall make its written determination on the request for review. Such determination shall be mailed or delivered to such person at the address set forth in the request for review. The decision of the city council may be subject to judicial review under Wis. Stats. § 68.13, in the manner provided for therein. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(e)) 
Sec. 46-403. - Application of state law. 
    Except as to those specific statutes expressly incorporated herein, the city elects not to be governed by any other provision of Wis. Stats. ch. 68, as amended. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(f)) 
Sec. 46-404. - Review and appeal costs. 
    In the event the city council does not modify or reverse the administrative determination in question following the hearing thereon, or in the event the administrative determination is sustained on appeal under Wis. Stats. § 68.13, then in either of such events, the person who has sought the review shall reimburse the city for all hearing and court costs incurred, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Code 1993, § 13.10(10)(g)) 
Secs. 46-405-46-421. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-422. - Purpose and intent. 
    Residents of the city depend exclusively on groundwater for a safe drinking water supply. Certain land use practices and activities can seriously threaten or degrade groundwater quality. The purpose of this article is to institute land use regulations and restrictions to protect the city's municipal water supply and well fields and to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(2)) 
Sec. 46-423. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aquifer means a saturated, permeable geologic formation that contains and will yield significant quantities of water. 
    Existing facilities which may cause or threaten to cause environmental pollution means existing facilities which may cause or threaten to cause environmental pollution within the corporate limits of the city's well fields' recharge areas which include, but are not limited to, the state department of natural resources' draft list of Inventory of Sites or Facilities Which May Cause or Threaten to Cause Environmental Pollution;" the Wisconsin Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations (hereafter DILHR) list of Underground Storage Tanks (hereafter USTs); and the DILHR list of facilities with hazardous solid waste permits, all of which are incorporated herein as if fully set forth herein. 
    Groundwater protection overlay districts means areas in the city which contains recharge area, or zones of influence for the city's wells where contamination is of particular concern, which shall be more specifically defined as those areas contained in the map incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth. 
    Recharge area means an area in which water reaches the zone of saturation by surface infiltration and encompasses all areas or features that supply groundwater recharge to a well. This area extends beyond the corporate limits of the city. 
    Well field means a piece of land used primarily for the purpose of supplying a location for construction of wells to supply a municipal water system. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(3)) 
Sec. 46-424. - Authority; application. 
    These regulations are established pursuant to the authority granted by the state legislature in 1983, Wisconsin Act 410 (effective May 11, 1984), which specifically added groundwater protection to the statutory authorization for municipal planning and zoning in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare. The regulations specified in this section shall apply only within the city's corporate limits. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(2)) 
Sec. 46-425. - Penalties. 
(a)  In the event the individual or facility causes the release of any contaminants which endanger the groundwater protection overlay district, the activity causing the release shall immediately cease and desist and cleanup satisfactory to the city shall occur. 
(b)  The individual/facility causing the release of contaminants shall be responsible for all costs of cleanup and the city consultant fees at the invoice amount, plus administrative costs for oversight, review and documentation, including the following: 
(1)  The cost of city employees' time associated in any way with the cleanup based on the hourly rate paid to the employee multiplied by a factor determined by the city, representing the city's cost for expenses, benefits, insurance, sick leave, holidays, overtime, vacation and similar benefits. 
(2)  The cost of city equipment employed. 
(3)  The cost of mileage reimbursed to the city employees attributed to the cleanup. 
(c)  Following any such discharge, the city may require additional test monitoring, posting of bond, or other requirements. 
(d)  In addition, any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof for each violation, forfeit not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, plus the cost of the prosecution and, in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs, shall be imprisoned in the county jail until payment thereof, but not exceeding 30 days or, in the alternative, shall have the cost added to their real estate property tax bill as a lien against the property. Each day a violation exists or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(8)) 
Secs. 46-426-46-448. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LAND USE RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 46-449. - Use restricted. 
    No person shall construct or use any structure, land or water in violation of the provisions of this article. Any person who is specifically damaged by such violations may institute appropriate action or proceedings to enjoin a violation of this section. Violations of this division are punishable as set forth article. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(8)) 
Sec. 46-450. - Minimum separation distances. 
    The following minimum separation distances shall be maintained where such distances existed at the time of the creation of the groundwater overlay districts: 
(1)  Fifty feet between a well and a storm sewer main. 
(2)  Two hundred feet between a well and any sanitary sewer main, lift station or single-family residential fuel oil tank. A lesser separation distance may be allowed for sanitary sewer mains where the sanitary sewer main is constructed of water main materials and joints and pressure-tested in place to meet current AWWA 600 specifications. In no case may the separation distance between a well and a sanitary sewer main be less than 50 feet. 
(3)  Four hundred feet between a well and a septic tank receiving less than 8,000 gallons per day, a cemetery or a stormwater drainage pond. 
(4)  Six hundred feet between a well and any gasoline or fuel oil storage tank installation that has received written approval from the state department of industry, labor and human relations or its designated agent under Wis. Admin. Code ch. ILHR 10.10. 
(5)  One thousand feet between a well and land application of municipal, commercial or industrial waste; industrial, commercial or municipal wastewater lagoons or storage structures; manure stacks or storage structures; and septic tanks or soil adsorption units receiving 8,000 gallons per day or more. 
(6)  Twelve hundred feet between a well and any solid waste storage, transportation, transfer, incineration, air curtain destructor, processing, wood burning, one time disposal or small demolition facility; sanitary landfill; coal storage area; salt or de-icing material storage area; gasoline or fuel oil storage tanks that have not received written approval from the state department of industry, labor and human relations or its designated agent under Wis. Admin. Code ch. ILHR 10.10; bulk fuel storage facilities; and pesticide or fertilizer handling or storage facilities. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(4)) 
Sec. 46-451. - Groundwater protection overlay district zones. 
    Land uses within the groundwater overlay district shall be regulated according to the zones defined in this article. The location and boundaries of the zoning districts are set forth on the map which is incorporated herein by reference. The map, together with everything shown thereon and all amendments thereto, shall be as much a part of this section as though fully set forth. The location and boundaries of the zoning districts established by this section are set forth in the descriptions attached to the map incorporated herein. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(5)) 
Sec. 46-452. - Zone A restrictions. 
(a)  Zone identified. Zone A is identified as the primary source of water for the municipal well aquifer and as the area most likely to transmit groundwater contamination to the municipal wells. Zone A is more restrictive than zone B or zone C. 
(b)  Permitted uses. Following uses are the permitted uses within the groundwater protection zone A. Uses not listed are to be considered prohibited uses. 
(1)  Parks, provided there is no on-site waste disposal or fuel storage tank facilities associated with this use. 
(2)  Playgrounds. 
(3)  Wildlife areas. 
(4)  Nonmotorized trails, such as bike, skiing, nature and fitness trails. 
(5)  Residential property, municipally sewered and free of flammable and combustible liquid and USTs. 
(c)  Prohibited uses. The following are examples of uses which are prohibited and not eligible for permits under the city zoning code: 
(1)  USTs of any size. 
(2)  Pesticide or fertilizer storage, use or mixing. 
(3)  Septic or sewage sludge spreading. 
(4)  Animal waste facilities. 
(5)  Gas stations. 
(6)  Bus or truck terminals. 
(7)  Landfills or waste disposal facilities. 
(8)  Spray wastewater facilities. 
(9)  Junkyards or auto salvage yards. 
(10)  Commercial bulk fertilizer or pesticide facilities. 
(11)  Asphalt products manufacturing. 
(12)  Salt storage. 
(13)  Toxic and hazardous waste facilities. 
(14)  Recycling facilities. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(5)) 
Sec. 46-453. - Zone B restrictions. 
(a)  Zone B identified. Zone B is identified as a secondary source of water for the municipal wells because of the zone of influence caused by pumping and a greater time of travel. Zone B is less restrictive than zone A, but more restrictive than zone C. 
(b)  Permitted uses. Following are the permitted uses within the groundwater protection zone B. Uses not listed are to be considered prohibited uses: 
(1)  All uses listed as permitted uses in zone A. 
(2)  Modified agricultural activities, including any crop free of pesticides or synthetic fertilizers. 
(3)  Aboveground petroleum product storage tanks less than 660 gallons. All new or replaced tanks shall be installed in compliance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. ILHR 10. 
(4)  Residential and commercial sewered property with a state-approved sewer and septic system. 
(c)  Prohibited uses. All uses listed as prohibited uses in zone A are examples of uses which are prohibited in zone B and are eligible for permits from the public works and utilities commission. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(5)) 
Sec. 46-454. - Zone C restrictions. 
(a)  Zone C identified. Zone C is identified as the groundwater protection overlay district, excluding those areas within zone A and zone B. 
(b)  Permitted uses. All uses listed as permitted in zone A and zone B. Individuals or facilities may make a request to the public works and utilities commission to permit additional land uses in zone C. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(5)) 
Secs. 46-455-46-476. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXISTING LAND USES 

Sec. 46-477. - Approvals and certificate to be provided. 
    Facilities shall provide copies of all federal, state and local facility operation approvals or certificates and ongoing environmental monitoring results to the city and shall provide additional environmental or safety monitoring as deemed necessary by the city public works and utilities commission, specifically including the production of any and all environmental statements detailing the extent of chemical use and storage on the property. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(7)) 
Sec. 46-478. - Replacement or expansion of equipment. 
    Facilities shall replace equipment or expand in a manner that improves the existing environmental and safety technologies already in existence. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(7)) 
Sec. 46-479. - Contingency emergency plan. 
    Facilities shall have the responsibility of devising or filing with the city a contingency plan satisfactory to the public works and utilities commission for the immediate notification of the appropriate city officials in the event of an emergency. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(7)) 
Sec. 46-480. - Agricultural use exempted. 
    Property owners with an existing agricultural use shall be exempt from the requirements of this section as they relate to restrictions on agricultural uses; provided, however, that such exemption shall apply only to the property owners in existence at the time of passage of this section and this exemption shall not constitute a covenant running with the land. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(7)) 
Secs. 46-481-46-498. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROPOSED NEW LAND USES 

Sec. 46-499. - Review of application. 
    The city public works and utilities commission shall review all requests for approval of new proposed land uses and all determinations shall be made by the city public works and utilities commission within 60 days of any request for approval provided, however, that this 60-day period of limitation may be extended by the city public works and utilities commission for good cause as determined in the sole and absolute discretion of the city public works and utilities commission. 
(Code 1993, § 13.38(6)) 
Sec. 46-500. - Factors considered in review. 
    Upon reviewing all requests for approval, the city public works and utilities commission shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The city's responsibility as a public water supplier to protect and preserve the health, safety and welfare of its citizens. 
(2)  The degree to which the proposed land use practice, activity or facility may seriously threaten or degrade groundwater quality in the city or the city recharge area.
